question: When a firm is investing in assets covering technical provisions for linked long-term contracts of insurance, in what circumstances must it still apply the PRA’s expectation to limit its investment where there is insufficient data to quantify asset risks, and when is that expectation outside scope?
gold_answer: The PRA’s expectation that a firm should limit its investment appropriately where there is insufficient data to quantify the risks arises when the firm is considering the nature and quantification of risks for each category of asset and for individual assets [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8]. However, the scope of the relevant part of the chapter is restricted for firms investing in assets that cover technical provisions (TPs) for linked long-term contracts of insurance: those provisions do not apply to such firms, except in a specific carve-in [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. The carve-in is where the assets are held to cover the additional TPs in respect of policyholder liabilities, including liabilities for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit provided under those linked long-term contracts [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6]. Accordingly, the firm should treat the expectation to limit investment due to insufficient risk data as applicable when the assets fall within that exception (ie, held for additional TPs tied to policyholder liabilities and guarantees), and as not applicable under this chapter where the assets merely cover TPs for linked long-term contracts without meeting the exception [#SRC:e5c80b0f218c00c6] [#TGT:f36a81ef70fe60e8].
source_text: Paragraphs 3.4 to 3.24 of this chapter do not apply to firms investing in assets covering technical provisions (TPs) for linked long-term contracts of insurance, except where the assets are held to cover the additional TPs in respect of policyholder liabilities, including those for any guarantee of investment performance or other guaranteed benefit provided under those contracts.
target_text: In considering the nature and quantification of the risks associated with each category of asset and with individual assets (see paragraph 3.14 of this SS), the PRA expects a firm to limit its investment appropriately where there is insufficient data to quantify the risks.

question: If a credit union is expected by the PRA to follow concentration limits because it is over £10 million in assets or holds certain investments, do those limits still apply when money is only sitting in an account for a short time before an investment decision is made?
gold_answer: Reading the two statements together, the PRA sets an expectation that certain credit unions should adhere to concentration limits: specifically, credit unions with more than £10 million in total assets and any credit unions that hold investments that fall under the referenced Rules, with an additional note that there are exceptions for certain listed investments. At the same time, the PRA also explains that the limits are not intended to apply in a particular, narrow situation—where funds are held temporarily in an account before an investment decision is made. So, even if a credit union is within the group the PRA expects to follow the concentration limits, it can treat those limits as not applying to money that is merely parked on a short-term basis while the credit union has not yet decided how to invest it. The key boundary is the purpose and timing of the holding: the carve-out is tied to pre-decision, temporary holding, whereas the expectation to adhere to concentration limits is directed at credit unions meeting the asset-size or investment-holding conditions, subject to the separate investment exceptions. question: When an Institution is permitted to compute one exposure value across transactions under a contractual netting agreement (subject to the relevant conditions), what must it do in terms of notifying the competent authorities about the calculation method it uses or ceases to use for determining exposure values for derivative positions?
gold_answer: Where Institutions choose to calculate exposure values for derivative positions using a particular method, they have a notification duty: they shall notify the competent authorities of the methods they use, or cease to use, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions [#SRC:7085c26bac1b91bb]. That obligation applies alongside the permission in the netting context: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all transactions within a contractual netting agreement only where the specified conditions are met; if those conditions are not met, Institutions must instead calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, treating each transaction as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Practically, this means that whenever an Institution adopts (or stops using) a method to support either (i) a single exposure value approach for transactions within a contractual netting agreement, or (ii) separate exposure value calculations per transaction, it must notify the competent authorities of the relevant method change or continued use. The notification requirement is framed around the methods used to calculate exposure values, not around the netting permission itself, so Institutions should ensure their notifications align with the method(s) actually applied to the exposure value calculations in either scenario.
source_text: Institutions shall notify the competent authorities of the methods set out in Section 4 or 5 that they use, or cease to use, as applicable, to calculate the exposure value of their derivative positions.
target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: After a liability is first recorded, must a firm (and an insurance or reinsurance undertaking) avoid changing the valuation just because its own credit standing changes?
gold_answer: Yes. The TARGET sets a two-step requirement for a firm: it must value financial liabilities (as referred to in UK-adopted international accounting standards) in the required way when the liability is first recognised, and then it must not make any later adjustment that takes account of a change in the firm’s own credit standing after that initial recognition [#TGT:f26605efb3832de6]. The SOURCE expresses the same type of restriction for a different actor and in a “subsequently” context: it states that there shall be no valuation adjustment to take account of the change in own credit standing of the insurance or reinsurance undertaking [#SRC:d6c3553c96db7f71]. Taken together, the practical rule is consistent across both texts: once the liability valuation is established at the relevant recognition point, later movements in the entity’s own credit standing are not a permitted reason to adjust the valuation. The main difference is only who is being addressed (a firm versus an insurance or reinsurance undertaking) and the explicit linkage in the TARGET to initial recognition and subsequent adjustments.

question: If the FSCS cannot recover some amounts from DGS members because of the levy process, must the FSCS still stay within the yearly levy cap, and when (if ever) can it charge more?
gold_answer: Yes. Even if there are amounts that the FSCS has not been able to recover from DGS members as a result of the relevant levy outcomes described in the source, the FSCS is still constrained by the rule that sets a maximum annual amount of DGS compensation costs it can levy on DGS members [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380]. Specifically, the FSCS must not set the maximum amount of DGS compensation costs for which it can levy DGS members per calendar year above 0.5% of total covered deposits (excluding temporary high balances) of all DGS members [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860]. The unrecovered-amounts situation explains that some sums may remain unpaid or uncollected from DGS members, but it does not itself authorize the FSCS to exceed the cap [#SRC:9b7ae1567f99f380]. The only stated way the FSCS can levy more than the cap is if there are exceptional circumstances and the FSCS has the prior consent of the PRA; without that consent (and without exceptional circumstances), charging above the cap is prohibited [#TGT:ba641d05400bc860].

question: For the PRA’s expectation about branches maintaining a threshold level of FSCS-covered retail and small company deposits, how must a firm determine whether the relevant balances are held in an “instant access account,” and what operational feature of the account is decisive for that classification?
gold_answer: To apply the PRA’s expectation for branches regarding the level of FSCS-covered retail and small company instant access deposit balances, the firm must first classify which account balances qualify as being in an “instant access account,” because the expectation is specifically framed around “FSCS covered instant access deposits” held at branches and kept under the stated threshold [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad]. The decisive feature for that classification is the customer’s withdrawal right: an instant access account is one from which customers can withdraw money unconditionally, and they must be able to do so without having to provide notice and without paying penalties [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3]. Accordingly, when assessing whether branch-held retail and small company balances fall within the scope of the PRA’s expectation, the firm should treat balances as “instant access” only where the account terms and actual customer access allow unconditional withdrawals with no notice requirement and no penalty. Balances in accounts that impose notice periods, conditionality, or withdrawal penalties would not meet the definition and therefore should not be counted as instant access for purposes of applying the branch expectation on FSCS-covered balances [#SRC:5ad52e36aa024bad] [#TGT:9a140c49d56502b3].

question: Where a credit union proposes to offer shares within an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper and also intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, what must it do to ensure it is referring to the relevant regulations and meeting all statutory mandatory requirements before commencing the fixed-rate activity, and how should it treat any HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) approval in its compliance assessment?
gold_answer: A credit union that wishes to offer shares in an Individual Savings Account (ISA) tax-free wrapper is expected to refer to the relevant regulations issued by HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC), and it must not treat HMRC approval as reducing or displacing its need to comply with statutory requirements [#SRC:39468cc7f2d4556d]. In parallel, where the same credit union intends to issue fixed-rate shares or deposits, the PRA expects it to comply with the statutory mandatory requirements that must be satisfied before beginning that activity [#TGT:bb34e94b2a68af4b]. Read together, the obligations require the credit union to (i) consult and follow the applicable HMRC regulatory framework for the ISA wrapper, (ii) recognise that obtaining HMRC approval does not provide any exemption from statutory compliance duties, and (iii) ensure that all statutory mandatory preconditions for issuing fixed-rate shares or deposits are met before it starts offering or issuing those products. The compliance approach should therefore treat HMRC approval as separate from, and not a substitute for, satisfying the statutory mandatory requirements expected by the PRA prior to commencement.

question: If a firm has a matching adjustment permission, what must it do to (1) find all uncertainties in the timing and amount of cash-flows for highly predictable cash-flow assets in the relevant portfolio, and (2) make sure the SCR calculation reflects how those uncertainties could change the fundamental spread, matching adjustment, and expected cash-flow patterns under stress?
gold_answer: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty about the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio where cash-flows are highly predictable, so the firm can understand what could cause cash-flows to differ from expectations [#TGT:e9d53c2edcdb5a35]. The firm must then ensure its SCR captures all material and quantifiable risks it is exposed to, and that the SCR calculation allows for changes to the fundamental spread and matching adjustment after a stress event [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. This means the firm should determine the risks affecting the matching adjustment portfolio, consider how those risks could affect the fundamental spread and matching adjustment, and assess how that effect is captured within the SCR calculation [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1]. In stress conditions, the firm should include changes to additions made to the fundamental spread used to calculate technical provisions, including additions made through the attestation process, and for assets with highly predictable cash flows the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash-flow pattern and any related fundamental spread additions [#SRC:c6705600c498e9a1].
source_text: A firm’s SCR should capture all material and quantifiable risks 6 to which it is exposed. The calculation of the SCR should therefore allow for any changes to the FS and MA following a stress event. In doing this, firms should determine the risks to which the MA portfolio is exposed, how these risks could affect the FS and MA and assess how this impact is captured within the SCR calculation. Changes to the FS in stress conditions should include any changes to additions made to the FS used to calculate the TPs, including those made as part of the attestation process. For assets with HP cash flows, the SCR should specifically allow for changes to the expected cash flow pattern on these assets as well as any changes to any FS additions made in line with Matching Adjustment 8 .
target_text: A firm with a matching adjustment permission must identify all sources of uncertainty regarding the timing and amount of cash-flows from any asset in the relevant portfolio of assets with cash-flows that are highly predictable .

question: When the PRA assesses the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, how must it treat any excess of a buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom over that entity’s share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk, and in what circumstances would the PRA not carry that difference into the consolidated group PRA buffer because the risk is otherwise addressed in consolidated group requirements?
gold_answer: In assessing the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk, the PRA’s assessment is informed by the extent to which any buffer applicable to an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applicable at the consolidated group level for covering the same risk [#SRC:fe2dce1c22203901]. However, the PRA would not reflect that excess (i.e., the difference between the outside-UK entity’s applicable buffer and its share of the consolidated group buffer for the same risk) in the consolidated group PRA buffer where the underlying risk of the entity established outside the United Kingdom is otherwise mitigated in the consolidated group requirements [#TGT:78474634e148d6b8]. Read together, the source establishes that the outside-UK buffer differential is a relevant input to the PRA’s consolidated group buffer assessment for group risk, while the target clarifies a limiting condition: the PRA would exclude that differential from the consolidated group PRA buffer when consolidated group requirements already mitigate the underlying risk associated with the outside-UK entity. This frames both the informational role of the differential and the circumstance in which it is not carried through into the consolidated group PRA buffer.
source_text: The PRA’s assessment of the total amount of the PRA buffer at consolidated group level for group risk will be informed by the amount by which any buffer applicable on an entity established outside the United Kingdom exceeds that entity’s share of the buffer applicable at the consolidated group level to cover the same risk. 50 51

question: For the purposes of Identification of Key Functions, what must the firm do to determine the scope of functions to be treated as key, and how should that determination be framed in terms of the firm’s own assessment?
gold_answer: Under the Identification of Key Functions requirement, the firm must carry out an identification exercise focused on determining which functions fall within the category of “key functions.” The scope of that exercise is not abstract or generic; it is anchored to the firm’s own view of what qualifies as a key function. In practice, this means the firm should identify, as part of its Identification of Key Functions process, each function that it considers to be a key function, ensuring the output is a complete set of those functions as assessed by the firm. The SOURCE establishes that the relevant compliance focus is the Identification of Key Functions topic itself [#SRC:4b63d605a75385d7]. The TARGET then specifies the concrete identification deliverable: the firm must capture each of the functions that the firm considers to be a key function [#TGT:0254821a38c334e7]. Read together, the firm’s obligation is to perform and document an identification that is comprehensive across all functions the firm itself classifies as key, rather than selecting only some or relying on an external list.

question: If a firm has to reduce the total value of its assets under the reduction rules, does it have to do it by deducting from the assets it would otherwise be allowed to count, and is the reduction amount the total of the items that make up the required aggregate reduction?
gold_answer: Yes. The reduction is required to be carried out by making a deduction from the aggregate value of the assets that the firm would otherwise be permitted to take into account for the relevant purposes. That tells you how the firm must apply the reduction in practice: it is taken off the asset total that would otherwise be counted, rather than being handled as a separate adjustment outside the aggregate asset value. At the same time, the firm’s aggregate value of assets must be reduced by an amount that represents the aggregate of specified components, and that obligation applies subject to the related provisions that frame how the reduction operates. Putting both requirements together, the firm must first identify the reduction amount as the aggregate of the relevant items, and then implement that reduction by deducting that amount from the aggregate asset value it would otherwise be allowed to include. This ensures the reduction is both correctly calculated and correctly applied to the asset base [#TGT:f960c6353f214378] and [#SRC:583731155e8d0cf1].

question: If the firm is checking whether it has covered all SCR-related risks, what must its risk-management system include, and what must be true about the calibration so that all quantifiable risks (at least the named ones) are counted?
gold_answer: To check that SCR-related risks are fully covered, the firm must ensure its risk-management system is effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, and it must cover the risks to be included in the SCR calculation as well as risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]. At the same time, the firm must ensure the calibration is designed so that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]. In practice, this means the firm’s system must not only focus on the risks already reflected in the SCR calculation but also identify and cover any additional or partially captured risks, while the calibration requirement ensures that every quantifiable exposure—starting with the minimum set of specified risk types—is included in the firm’s quantified risk capture.

However, that table-based approach depends on the existence of a preceding financial year from which the firm’s highest annual contribution income can be identified. Where the firm has not been in existence long enough to have a preceding financial year, the definition provides a specific substitute amount: the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000 [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]. In practice, this means a newly established firm (or one without a completed preceding financial year) does not attempt to infer or approximate a “highest annual contribution income” for table selection; instead, it applies the fixed £90,000 minimum guarantee fund until it has a preceding financial year that enables the standard table correspondence to be used.

question: If you are checking limits on debts, how do you apply the 5% limit for the aggregate of debts of the relevant descriptions alongside the 1% limit for unsecured debts due or to become due from one counterparty (excluding debt securities terms and regulated institution debts, and excluding an individual, body corporate or group)?
gold_answer: You need to apply two separate percentage limits that address different scopes, and both can matter for the same set of exposures. One limit is 5% and it applies to “the aggregate of debts of the descriptions” identified in the source text, meaning you total up the debts that fall within those described categories (linked to 28.5, 28.6 and 28.7) and ensure the aggregate stays within 5% [#SRC:49457b0134191ba3]. The other limit is 1% and it applies to “all unsecured debts” that are due or to become due from any one counterparty, but only after excluding unsecured debts that arise under the terms of debt securities and excluding debts from a regulated institution; it also only applies where the counterparty is “other than an individual, body corporate or group” [#TGT:cd6a8143565de2fd]. So, for a qualifying counterparty, you must keep that counterparty’s unsecured-debt exposure within 1%, while also ensuring that the relevant described debts, in aggregate, do not exceed 5%.

question: When the firm is treated as having acquired or disposed of assets because it has achieved the effect of a contract by entering into appropriate futures contracts or options, how must the firm adjust the value ascribed under the relevant valuation provisions, and how must those deemed asset movements be handled for subsequent treatment?
gold_answer: Where the firm is deemed to have achieved the effect of a contract by entering into appropriate futures contracts or options, it follows that the firm is also deemed to have acquired or disposed of certain assets. First, the firm must adjust the value ascribed under the applicable valuation range by increasing or decreasing it by an amount that represents the value of the assets the firm is deemed to have acquired or disposed of under the relevant deeming basis [#TGT:490d874efaa81343]. Taken together, the obligation is to translate the deemed economic effect created through futures contracts or options into a corresponding valuation adjustment, and then to process the resulting deemed assets under the appropriate acquisition/disposal handling provisions.

question: When working out long-term insurance liabilities that are not already due before the valuation date, what must the determination do to follow actuarial principles and policyholder expectations, while also taking into account the type and length of the assets backing the liabilities and possible future changes in those asset values?
gold_answer: The determination must be carried out using generally accepted actuarial principles and must have due regard to the reasonable expectations of policyholders, while also making proper provision for all liabilities on prudent assumptions that include appropriate margins for adverse deviation [#TGT:33b30c26d9d90a62]. At the same time, the determination must take into account the nature and term of the assets representing those liabilities and the value placed on those assets, and it must include prudent provision against the effects of possible future changes in the value of the assets [#SRC:77cfb62c67129fc6]. In practice, this means you cannot value the liabilities in isolation: the approach and assumptions used to calculate the liabilities must be prudent and include margins, and they must be applied with an understanding of what assets are backing the liabilities, how long those assets run, and how changes in asset values could affect the adequacy of the provisions. The resulting figure should therefore reflect both actuarial prudence and asset-related risk prudence.

question: When you calculate RoA as net income divided by total assets and then average it over two years, what exact FINREP line must you use for the net income number?
gold_answer: RoA is calculated by taking net income as the numerator and total assets as the denominator, and then averaging that ratio over a two-year period, so you need a clear, consistent source for the net income input in each of the two years [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505]. The net income figure is explicitly defined by reference to FINREP: it must be the amount reported in row 355, column 01 of template F02.00 (FINREP) [#TGT:faed71864e571bf4]. Putting these together, the practical requirement is that, for each year included in the two-year average, you take net income from that specific FINREP row/column and divide it by total assets to compute the annual RoA ratio, and then average the two annual ratios [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505]. This approach ensures the numerator is not an internally selected “net income” concept but the defined FINREP data point, while still applying the RoA structure that uses total assets as the denominator and requires a two-year averaging method [#TGT:faed71864e571bf4].
source_text: RoA will be calculated as the ratio of net income 8 to total assets 9 , and averaged over two years.

question: When the Merger Document(s) are sent out with a covering letter, what exactly are the proxy voting forms meant to be, and what are they used for at a society meeting?
gold_answer: The proxy voting forms that may be included as “other documents” alongside a covering letter for the Merger Document(s) are not just generic voting papers; they are the formal instrument used to appoint a proxy. Their purpose is to let a member name someone else to attend a meeting of a society and vote for the member. So, in the merger materials package, the covering letter is an accompanying document, and the proxy voting forms are the mechanism that enables members who cannot attend to still participate through a proxy’s attendance and voting. This connection matters because the source indicates that proxy voting forms can be part of the documents provided with the Merger Document(s) [#SRC:81e3009351497661], and the target clarifies the meaning and function of that proxy instrument: it appoints a proxy to attend the society meeting and vote on the member’s behalf [#TGT:075179a0e3b09cfe].
source_text: (c) any other documents, such as a covering letter for the Merger Document(s) and proxy voting forms; 31
target_text: 31. An instrument appointing a proxy to attend a meeting of a society and vote on the member’s behalf.

question: When allocating responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm), what must a firm do in terms of establishing and maintaining policies and procedures to ensure compliance by the firm and its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents), and to counter financial crime risk?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure that the governance arrangements assigning responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function (including oversight of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm) are supported by adequate, operating controls. Specifically, the firm must establish, implement and maintain policies and procedures that are sufficient to ensure compliance by the firm and by its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents) with the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system, and that also counter the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime [#TGT:5ca4886f7aeb4304]. In practice, this means the firm’s compliance framework should be designed so that the compliance function can operate independently and be effectively overseen, with clear accountability for monitoring its performance and for supervising any FCA-approved individual performing compliance oversight on the firm’s behalf [#SRC:ee565fa3af708789]. The policies and procedures should therefore be adequate not only in design but also in implementation and ongoing maintenance, so they remain effective as the firm’s activities and risks evolve.
source_text: (16) responsibility for safeguarding the independence of, and overseeing the performance of, the compliance function, including the performance of a person approved by the FCA to perform the compliance oversight function on behalf of the firm , in accordance with Compliance and Internal Audit 2 (PR K) ;
target_text: A firm must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures sufficient to ensure compliance of the firm including its managers, employees and appointed representatives (or where applicable, tied agents ) with its obligations under the regulatory system and for countering the risk that the firm might be used to further financial crime .

question: When a firm outsources critical or important operational functions or activities to a service provider that is a member of the same group, what must the firm do to ensure the written outsourcing agreement remains aligned with the firm’s obligations while also reflecting the firm’s level of control or influence over the service provider?
gold_answer: In this scenario, the firm must do two things in parallel. First, it must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement governing the outsourcing are consistent with the firm’s obligations under the applicable requirements referenced in the source obligation, so the contract does not dilute, contradict, or omit what the firm is required to do [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]. Second, because the outsourcing is to a service provider within the same group and involves critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm must take into account the extent to which it controls the service provider or can influence its actions, and use that assessment to shape how it structures and manages the outsourcing arrangement [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5]. Practically, this means the firm should align contractual responsibilities, governance, and oversight mechanisms with both (i) its own regulatory obligations and (ii) the reality of intra-group control or influence, so that the agreement and the firm’s management of the arrangement remain coherent and enforceable across both sets of requirements.
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: Where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group , the firm must, when outsourcing any critical or important operational functions or activities, take into account the extent to which the firm controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.

question: How must firms evidence that they have considered additional recovery options at the UK subsidiary level (beyond parental support) and what must they include to demonstrate the practical executability of those options over time?
gold_answer: Firms must evidence in their plan that, even where parental support may be the most credible recovery option for a UK subsidiary within an international group, they have still considered what additional recovery options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and have set out those recovery options in the plan [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. This requires the plan to articulate the UK-specific options the firm could take locally, acknowledging that the set of options may be more limited for a subsidiary but not treating that limitation as a reason to omit subsidiary-level actions [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c]. To demonstrate that these options are not merely theoretical, firms should also include the timelines over which the recovery options could be implemented, so the plan shows the expected implementation horizon for each option and supports an assessment of feasibility and responsiveness [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8]. Where applicable, and particularly for O-SIIs, the options described should be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan, while still being presented with UK subsidiary specificity and associated implementation timelines [#SRC:feb6a610b0993e0c] [#TGT:f3e093c3fd6bc8e8].
source_text: (iii) The plan should include UK specific recovery options: the PRA recognises that as subsidiaries of international groups, firms may have a more limited set of recovery options at the level of the UK subsidiary and that parental support may be the most credible recovery option. However, the PRA expects firms to consider what additional options are available at the level of the UK subsidiary and set out its recovery options against the expectations set out in Chapter 2 (i) (b) , (c) , (d) , (e) , (f) , (g) and (ii) . For O-SIIs the PRA expects these options to be consistent with what is proposed in the group plan.
target_text: Firms should include the timelines over which recovery options could be implemented.

question: If a firm is doing benchmarking activities, does it still have to regularly check and test whether its systems and internal controls are working well and fix problems, or is that requirement limited by the rule that certain provisions do not apply except for pre‑IP completion day EU‑transposition purposes?
gold_answer: The requirement is that a firm must monitor and, on a regular basis, evaluate whether its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements are adequate and effective, and then take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies, but this duty is tied to the systems and arrangements established in accordance with the Chapter [#TGT:0b5d0c9bc5e714bd]. The scope text then narrows when and how the referenced provisions apply to a firm “with respect to” the carrying on of benchmarking activities: they do not apply, except to the extent that, before IP completion day, they were made for the purpose of transposing an EU instrument [#SRC:4583db85bf9943ef]. Putting these together, for benchmarking activities the firm must carry out the regular monitoring, evaluation, and corrective measures only to the extent the Chapter’s requirements apply under that limited pre‑IP completion day EU‑transposition carve‑in [#SRC:4583db85bf9943ef]. Outside that extent, the scope limitation means the firm is not required, for those benchmarking activities, to maintain and review systems and controls under this Chapter in the way described [#TGT:0b5d0c9bc5e714bd].
source_text: 2.1 to 2.8 do not apply to a firm with respect to the carrying on of benchmarking activities except to the extent that before IP completion day , they were made for the purpose of transposing an EU instrument...
target_text: A firm must monitor and, on a regular basis, evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements established in accordance with this Chapter and take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies.

question: What does a third country branch need to do to regularly check whether its systems and internal controls are working well and fix problems it finds, and how does this depend on the firm employing staff with the right skills and expertise for the responsibilities they are given?
gold_answer: A third country branch should have a routine approach to monitoring and regularly evaluating whether its systems, internal control mechanisms and governance arrangements are adequate and effective, and it should take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies it identifies through that process [#SRC:ccbb370053078096]. For that routine checking and fixing to be effective, the firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise needed to carry out the responsibilities allocated to them, considering the nature, scale and complexity of the business and the nature and range of financial services and activities it undertakes [#TGT:e5e58d967893ceaf]. Put together, the branch’s regular evaluation work should be assigned to people who are capable of performing it, and the people responsible for follow-up actions should be capable of designing and carrying out the measures needed to address deficiencies. The staffing requirement supports the branch’s ability to run the monitoring cycle properly and to ensure that identified weaknesses are addressed in a timely and competent way.
source_text: A third country branch should monitor and, on a regular basis, evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements established in accordance with the Internal Governance of Third Country Branches 5.1 and section 5 of this supervisory statement and take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies.
target_text: A firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise necessary for the discharge of the responsibilities allocated to them, taking into account the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of financial services and activities undertaken in the course of that business.

question: If an own funds item is issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, what must you do to classify it, and when are you not allowed to say it is free from encumbrances?
gold_answer: Where an own funds item has been issued by an insurance holding company, a mixed financial holding company, an intermediate holding company or an ancillary services undertaking in the group, you must classify the own funds item using the criteria for classification set out in Own Funds 3A – 3J, but only if the applicable requirements for using those criteria are met [#TGT:e82491299baf128a]. At the same time, you must not treat the item as free from encumbrances unless a specific condition about claim ranking is satisfied: the claims relating to the own funds item must rank after the claims of all policyholders of the Solvency II undertakings belonging to the group [#SRC:bc73a26522603455]. So, when you are doing the classification required for these issuer types, you need to check how the claims on the item rank compared with those policyholder claims. If the item’s claims do not rank after all such policyholder claims, then it is prohibited to consider the item free from encumbrances, and your classification work must proceed without that assumption, aligning the classification obligation [#TGT:e82491299baf128a] with the encumbrance restriction [#SRC:bc73a26522603455].

question: If a firm is an originator, original lender, or sponsor in a securitisation, what does the PRA expect the internal audit function to check, and how should it make sure the deal does not use underlying exposures that include securitisation positions?
gold_answer: When a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction that is subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation complies with the relevant requirements in that framework [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b]. A key part of that assurance should be confirming that the securitisation’s underlying exposures meet the prohibition on what can be included in the pool: the underlying exposures used in a securitisation must not include securitisation positions [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb]. To satisfy the PRA’s expectation, the internal audit function should therefore review how the firm is involved in the transaction (in its capacity as originator, original lender, and/or sponsor) and also verify, based on the transaction’s underlying exposures, that no securitisation positions are included. This links the internal audit assurance obligation about the firm’s compliant involvement [#SRC:cecc17757525a70b] with the specific prohibited feature of the securitisation’s exposure composition [#TGT:d7fccee9ffee99cb].
source_text: Where a firm acts as an originator, original lender, and/or sponsor in a transaction subject to the requirements of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook, the PRA expects the firm’s internal audit function to provide assurance that the firm’s involvement in the securitisation is compliant with the requirements in Articles 6 , 7 , 8 and 9 of Chapter 2 and Chapters 4-6 of the Securitisation Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: The underlying exposures used in a securitisation shall not include securitisation positions .

question: What must a firm do to keep enough liquid assets to pay liabilities when they are due, and how does this connect to the expectation that an insurer holds a liquidity buffer and monitors liquid assets (including possible haircuts on sale)?
gold_answer: A firm must hold and maintain liquid assets that are sufficient to meet its liabilities as they become due [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855]. The related expectation for an insurer is more specific about how to achieve that outcome: it must maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets (a liquidity buffer) sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and it is expected to be able to do so under both benign and stressed conditions [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0]. To support this, the insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer, and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale, which could reduce the cash actually available when assets are liquidated [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0]. Read together, the requirement is not only to have liquid assets on paper, but to ensure the portfolio and buffer are managed and monitored so that liabilities can be met when due in normal and stressed environments [#SRC:69f861caa7c533e0] while still satisfying the baseline obligation to meet liabilities as they become due [#TGT:2f72bbe695968855].
source_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.
target_text: A firm must maintain liquid assets sufficient to meet its liabilities as they become due.

question: When a delinquent loan is rescheduled or its arrears are added to the balance, what do all directors need to check regularly to be sure their credit union is following the provisioning requirements, and how long must the pre-change provision be kept?
gold_answer: All directors are expected to regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union is accurately complying with the provisioning requirements [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f]. That regular check must include what happens when the credit union deals with a delinquent loan by rescheduling it or by capitalising the arrears, because the provisioning treatment is not reset just because the loan terms change. In those cases, the credit union must keep the provision that it was required to hold immediately before the rescheduling or recapitalisation, and it must continue to maintain that same provision until the loan has performed for six months [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff]. So, directors should ensure the credit union (1) identifies the correct provision level right before the loan is rescheduled or arrears are capitalised, and (2) does not reduce that provision during the following period, only allowing a change after the loan has performed for the full six months required [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff], as part of accurate compliance oversight [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f].
source_text: The PRA expects that all directors regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union accurately complies with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears capitalised, the provision a credit union is required to make immediately prior to the rescheduling or recapitalisation must be maintained until the loan has performed for six months.

question: If a firm is the parent entity of an international group, what must it show in its group recovery plan about entities in other jurisdictions, and how must it explain the links between recovery options (including options that cannot be used together) given dependencies between group entities?
gold_answer: A firm that is a parent entity of an international group must demonstrate in its group recovery plan how it has covered the different entities in other jurisdictions, so the plan clearly addresses the wider group and not just a single entity or location [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. The PRA also expects the firm to understand dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, because these relationships can affect whether and how recovery actions can be carried out across the group [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. Alongside this, the firm must detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive, so it is transparent which options rely on others and which options cannot be pursued at the same time [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6]. In practice, the plan should therefore link the coverage of each relevant group entity (including those in other jurisdictions) with a clear explanation of how recovery options interact, so that the overall recovery approach is internally consistent and any constraints created by group-wide dependencies are explicitly set out [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: When an institution is required to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions within a six‑month period after a triggering event, can it still apply netting to compute a single exposure value across transactions under a contractual netting agreement, and what calculation approach applies if the netting conditions are not met?
gold_answer: The institution’s starting point is that it has a time‑bound obligation to stop calculating exposure values for its derivative positions under the specified calculation approach within six months after a relevant trigger occurs [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7]. Separately, the framework permits institutions to calculate one combined exposure value for all transactions covered by a contractual netting agreement, but only where all the stated conditions for that netting treatment are met [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. If those netting conditions are not met, the institution is not permitted to aggregate and instead must calculate an exposure value for each transaction on a standalone basis, with each transaction treated as its own netting set [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c]. Read together, the permission to use a single exposure value under qualifying contractual netting does not remove or extend the separate requirement to cease the specified exposure‑value calculation method within the six‑month window; rather, it governs how exposure values may be determined (single netted value versus separate transaction values) in the circumstances where exposure values are being calculated [#SRC:e840f5f94a52b4e7] [#TGT:2e5deb9d3290fa4c].

target_text: Institutions may calculate a single exposure value for all the transactions within a contractual netting agreement where all the conditions set out in Article 274(1) are met. Otherwise, institutions shall calculate an exposure value separately for each transaction, which shall be treated as its own netting set.

question: If a credit union must make sure a member’s total non-deferred shares do not go over the allowed maximum, does it have to count an increase in the percentage of non-deferred shares held by that member when checking the limits, and what conditions apply?
gold_answer: The credit union’s compliance check must combine the TARGET obligation with the SOURCE counting rule. Under the TARGET, Subject to 2.3 and 2.4, a credit union must ensure that a member does not have non-deferred shares in the credit union which in aggregate exceed the greater of the applicable limit. When assessing that requirement against the limits in 2.2, the SOURCE provides a specific treatment for a particular type of change: “the increase in the percentage of the non-deferred shares held by that member is disregarded for the purposes of the limits in 2.2.” Practically, this means that if the member’s position involves an increase in the percentage of non-deferred shares held by that member, the credit union should not count that percentage increase when applying the limits in 2.2 as part of determining whether the member’s aggregate non-deferred shares exceed the greater-of cap described in the TARGET. The credit union must still perform the aggregation and ensure the member does not exceed the maximum, but it must do so while disregarding that percentage increase for the stated purpose and within the “Subject to 2.3 and 2.4” conditions. question: In meeting the obligation to project TWD scenario impacts through the wind-down period, how should TWD firms align their methodologies, models, and frameworks with the requirement to include all necessary risk and trade data, particularly where projections depend on sensitivity analysis and alternative segmentation of trading portfolios?
gold_answer: TWD firms should align their methodologies, models, and frameworks with the scope and granularity of the inputs required to run them, so that projections remain supportable from the reference date through the wind-down period. The obligation to forecast the impact of the TWD scenario on capital requirements, capital resources, and liquidity presupposes that the firm’s analytical toolkit can generate projections over the relevant horizon [#TGT:eecba58e91b8b36e]. That toolkit must be underpinned by a dataset that includes all risk and trade data necessary to calculate financial impact projections and sensitivity analysis, rather than a partial or high-level subset [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. The same data should also support segmentation of TWD firms’ trading portfolios in multiple ways, enabling the firm to reflect different portfolio groupings that may be used to execute wind-down actions (including alternative packaging of trades for novation) [#SRC:735b1160d0a31510]. Together, these requirements mean the firm’s models and frameworks should be designed to consume and reconcile portfolio segmentations and sensitivities so that capital and liquidity forecasts remain coherent under different wind-down execution paths.

question: If a firm is planning a material change to its booking arrangements that could change how its risk management works, what should it do about telling the PRA, and how does this connect to the requirement that the firm must be ready for an orderly resolution with minimal disruption of critical services?
gold_answer: If a firm plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements and those changes could impact how its risk management operates, the PRA expects the firm to inform the PRA about what it is planning [#SRC:9efcdb7da1784680]. This expectation should be understood alongside the firm’s obligation to prepare for resolution so that, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]. In practical terms, the firm should treat planned booking-arrangement changes as potentially relevant not only to risk management but also to resolvability: how the firm books business can influence how risks are managed and how the firm could be resolved while maintaining critical services. So, when planning material booking changes that could affect risk management, the firm should notify the PRA and ensure its organisation of booking arrangements continues to support both effective risk management and readiness for orderly resolution with minimal disruption.
source_text: The PRA has a number of expectations concerning how international banks and UK trading banks should organise their booking arrangements in order to meet the threshold condition on the prudent conduct of business, their obligations under Fundamental Rules 3 , 5 , 6 and 8 , and under the General Organisational Requirements (GOR) relating to risk management and resolvability. The PRA also has an expectation under Fundamental Rule 7 and General Notification Requirement 2.3(1) that a firm should inform the PRA when it plans to make material changes to its booking arrangements that could impact how its risk management operates.
target_text: Fundamental Rule 8: A firm must prepare for resolution so, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services.

question: A TWD firm must be able to run sensitivity analysis on key assumptions. How should it use that analysis to show the range of impacts on capital and liquidity while still building its TWD capabilities on a full wind-down of its trading activities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to conduct sensitivity analysis that measures how changing key assumptions (compared with those used in the TWD scenario) affects outcomes, and it should use that capability to set out upper and lower bounds for those assumptions so senior management can see the range of plausible impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections after the TWD option is executed [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. At the same time, the firm should treat this sensitivity analysis as supporting work that sits within, and does not alter, the expectation that the firm’s TWD capabilities are built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities [#TGT:67153071a209f68a]. The sensitivity analysis capability should include the ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors that form part of the TWD scenario, and then vary assumptions around that baseline to quantify how projections move under different plausible conditions [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. In other words, the firm uses sensitivity analysis to stress and bound its wind-down planning assumptions, while keeping the overall capability design grounded in a full trading wind-down [#TGT:67153071a209f68a].
source_text: TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario. TWD firms should be able to use their sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out the upper and lower bounds for TWD firms’ key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on TWD firms’ capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option. This sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors (see paragraphs 3.6 - 3.15 for more detail).
target_text: This does not impact the expectation (set out in more detail in Chapter 4 ) that a TWD firm’s TWD capabilities should be built on the basis of the full wind-down of its trading activities.

question: When setting internal expectations for liquidity, what must the credit union do to ensure the maintained quantity and quality of liquid assets over time does not fall below the minimum level tied to total relevant liabilities?
gold_answer: The credit union must establish and operate an approach to liquidity that addresses both the quantity and the quality of liquid assets it maintains over time, explicitly taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements that apply to it [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce]. This obligation requires the credit union to look beyond a one-off calculation and instead ensure that its liquid asset holdings remain appropriate and sustainable as conditions change, while still meeting the minimum quantitative requirement. The minimum quantitative requirement is clear: a credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf]. Therefore, internal expectations and monitoring should be calibrated so that, at all times, the maintained stock of liquid assets is not only of sufficient quality and managed over time, but also remains at or above the 10% of total relevant liabilities threshold. In effect, the credit union’s ongoing maintenance of liquid assets (quantity and quality) must be designed so that the minimum percentage requirement is continuously satisfied as part of the overall liquidity position [#SRC:f2622a90a592c4ce] and not treated as a separate or occasional compliance check [#TGT:738a19e25819dedf].
source_text: the quantity and quality of liquid assets to be maintained by the credit union over time, taking into account the minimum liquidity requirements in Rule 9.2 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook; and
target_text: A credit union must hold liquid assets equal to at least 10% of its total relevant liabilities .

question: When a firm does not meet its combined buffer and is therefore subject to a maximum distributable amount, how must the firm determine the applicable percentage factor for the product-based calculation, and how does the firm’s quartile position in its combined buffer constrain the portion of the relevant profits that can be distributed?
gold_answer: Where a firm does not meet its combined buffer, it faces restrictions on distributions and becomes subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA), which it must calculate as a product of a specified percentage and a profits measure [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. The percentage factor is not discretionary: it must be selected from 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in, and that quartile-based mapping also defines the maximum portion of the relevant profits that can be distributed [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b]. Specifically, the quartiles are defined by how much of the combined buffer the firm meets: if the firm is in the first quartile (meeting between 75% and 100% of the combined buffer), it may distribute 60% of such profits; in the second quartile it may distribute 40%; in the third quartile 20%; and in the fourth quartile 0% [#TGT:f7a8dbc40adc919d]. The profits input to the product is the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits, net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from the items referenced in the calculation requirement [#SRC:f0d7eff2798e540b].
source_text: Firms may use their combined buffer as required in times of stress, but should not use it in the normal course of business or propose to enter it as part of their base business plan. As set out in the PRA’s capital buffers rules, firms that do not meet their combined buffer shall face restrictions on their distributions, and be subject to a maximum distributable amount (MDA). The MDA must be calculated as the product of 60%, 40%, 20% or 0% (depending on which quartile of its combined buffer the firm is in) 3 and the sum of the last four calendar quarter profits (as defined in Capital Buffers 4.3(5)), net of any distribution of profits or any payment resulting from:
target_text: 3. Where firms are in the first quartile of their combined buffer (when they meet between 75% and 100% of it), 60% of such profits can be distributed. In the second quartile, 40% can be distributed; in the third quartile, 20%; and in the fourth quartile, 0%.

question: If a firm wants to change its model change policy (not just admin edits), does it need PRA permission, and which September 2016 PRA document should it look at for more detail on changes to internal models?
gold_answer: Yes. If a firm changes the model change policy itself and the change is more than administrative, that change is subject to the PRA’s permission, so the firm should treat it as requiring PRA approval rather than as a routine internal update [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224]. This requirement is linked to the PRA’s broader expectation that firms review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and continues to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224]. For additional context on changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms, the referenced publication is SS12/16, which is dated September 2016 and is available via the Bank of England website [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998]. Taken together, the passages indicate that policy governance is part of model governance: regular review is encouraged, but substantive policy changes trigger a permission expectation, and the September 2016 document is the cited reference point.
source_text: The PRA encourages firms to review the effectiveness of the model change policy on a regular basis to ensure that the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and meets the internal model requirements and calibration standards. Firms are also reminded that changes to the model change policy itself, other than administrative changes, are subject to the PRA’s permission. Readers also are referred to SS12/16, ‘Changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms’ . 16
target_text: 16. September 2016: http://www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2016/solvency2-changes-to-internal-models-used-by-uk-insurance-firms-ss .

question: When identity verification has not been completed under the relevant anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, how should insolvency practitioners align their required consideration of their objectives and responsibilities with the ability for the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate identity verification to determine eligibility for FSCS protection?
gold_answer: Where identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA’s view is that the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court is permitted to facilitate the identity verification specifically for the purpose of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection [#SRC:eb355065b8865baf]. In parallel, insolvency practitioners are expected to consider matters in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:02363a43a51fdf7b]. Read together, this means the insolvency practitioner’s decision-making should not treat facilitation of identity verification as a standalone discretionary step; rather, it should be approached as an action that may be used to support the eligibility determination where the pre-compensation-date verification gap exists, while ensuring the practitioner’s overall approach remains consistent with their statutory objectives and responsibilities. The practical linkage is that the permitted facilitation addresses the missing verification needed to assess FSCS eligibility, and the required consideration frames how and why the practitioner proceeds in that context, given their role and responsibilities.
source_text: In the event that identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements referred to in Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA considers that Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) would allow the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate the identity verification for the purposes of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection. 2
target_text: 2. Insolvency practitioners should consider in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009.

question: If an entity is required to determine the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a prospective calculation, can it nonetheless apply a retrospective calculation for certain contracts or benefits, and what evidentiary threshold must be met to justify that permission?
gold_answer: The baseline requirement is that the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation, which sets the expected method for liability measurement across the portfolio [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. The permission to use a retrospective calculation operates only as a constrained carve-out from that default and applies only to determine the liabilities in specific cases [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]. One route is functional impossibility: where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, a retrospective calculation may be applied for those liabilities notwithstanding the general prospective requirement [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] alongside [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb]. The other route is an evidentiary demonstration: the entity must be able to demonstrate that the resulting amount of liabilities from the retrospective calculation would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation, meaning the retrospective result must not understate liabilities relative to a prudent prospective benchmark [#TGT:30f622a929df3844].
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: When an Authorised Person is preparing to make an application under the SoP, what PRA website resource should they consult for application instructions, and which specific supervisory statement (including its June 2024 version) should be used alongside that application guidance for internal model matching adjustment modelling?
gold_answer: In preparing to make an application, the SoP directs the Authorised Person to consult the Authorisations page of the PRA’s website for information about the application process, and to treat that application guidance as part of a wider set of materials that the SoP should be read in conjunction with [#SRC:6f1cefbb88e9a396]. Within that wider set, the SoP explicitly includes supervisory statement SS8/18 on internal models and the modelling of the matching adjustment, so the applicant should ensure they are using the current referenced publication for that topic when assembling their submission [#SRC:6f1cefbb88e9a396]. The cross-referenced item identifies the relevant document precisely as the TERM ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’, June 2024, and provides the Bank of England URL where that June 2024 version can be accessed [#TGT:ad88d1cd8dfc3d97]. Read together, these passages indicate that the application process information is obtained from the PRA Authorisations page, while the technical supervisory expectations for internal model matching adjustment modelling are drawn from the June 2024 version of ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’.
source_text: This SoP should be read in conjunction with the IRPR regulations, the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA Rulebook, the Investments Part of the PRA Rulebook, the relevant rules in the rest of the Solvency II Sector of the PRA Rulebook, supervisory statement (SS) 7/18 – Solvency II: Matching adjustment 1 , SS1/20 – Solvency II: Prudent Person Principle 2 , SS8/18 – Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment 3 , SS3/17 – Solvency II: Illiquid unrated assets 4 and the PRA’s insurance approach document. 5 For information about making an application, see the Authorisations page of the PRA’s website.
target_text: 3. ‘Solvency II: Internal models – modelling of the matching adjustment’, June 2024: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2018/solvency-2-internal-models-modelling-of-the-matching-adjustment-ss .

question: If regular reviews show weaknesses in a third country branch’s systems or internal controls, what actions are expected, and what does the firm need to do about staffing so the right people can carry out the assigned review and remediation responsibilities?
gold_answer: If a third country branch’s regular monitoring and evaluation shows that its systems, internal control mechanisms, or governance arrangements are not adequate or effective, it should take appropriate measures to address the deficiencies that have been identified [#SRC:ccbb370053078096]. To ensure those reviews and fixes are actually carried out properly, the firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise necessary for the responsibilities allocated to them, taking into account the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of financial services and activities undertaken [#TGT:e5e58d967893ceaf]. In practice, this means the branch should allocate review responsibilities to staff who can competently assess adequacy and effectiveness, and allocate remediation responsibilities to staff who can implement corrective measures. It also means staffing decisions should reflect how complex the branch’s business and activities are, because that complexity affects what skills and expertise are needed to identify and address deficiencies.
source_text: A third country branch should monitor and, on a regular basis, evaluate the adequacy and effectiveness of its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements established in accordance with the Internal Governance of Third Country Branches 5.1 and section 5 of this supervisory statement and take appropriate measures to address any deficiencies.
target_text: A firm must employ personnel with the skills, knowledge and expertise necessary for the discharge of the responsibilities allocated to them, taking into account the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of financial services and activities undertaken in the course of that business.

question: When an external auditor is appointed by a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking, what must the external auditor include in the report regarding how the information was compiled, and what limitation or condition applies to that obligation?
gold_answer: Where an external auditor is appointed by a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking, the external auditor has a mandatory reporting duty that links the appointment to specific content that must be stated in the report. In particular, the external auditor must state in the report that the information has been properly compiled in accordance with the relevant PRA rules and UK law relating to the undertaking, and that this compilation is based on information provided by undertakings in the group and the relevant insurance group undertaking [#SRC:eca198ee0fd1c158]. This obligation is not unconditional: the target provision frames the external auditor’s required actions as being subject to a stated condition (“Subject to 4.2”) and applies to an external auditor appointed by a firm or relevant insurance group undertaking pursuant to the appointment requirement referenced there [#TGT:911a28130622e256]. Read together, the appointment trigger in the target establishes when the external auditor’s “must” obligations apply, while the source specifies the concrete statement that must appear in the report and the basis on which the external auditor makes that statement.
