question: What must a firm use to calculate the class A tariff base, and what information standard must it meet at the valuation date—especially for accounts with safeguarded funds or funds the account holder is not absolutely entitled to, and for any funds the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits?
gold_answer: A firm must calculate the Class A tariff base using covered deposits from the SCV file, and it must base that calculation on the information it would have to include in its single customer views [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1] [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. The information used cannot be a reduced or informal dataset: it must be of the extent and standard that would be required if the firm were preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base [#TGT:cd1f61ae71a25acf]. When assembling the deposit balances that feed into the covered-deposit calculation, the firm must include the total balance of deposits in any account that holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or that are safeguarded funds, because those balances must be included under the rules for the calculation basis [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1]. At the same time, the firm may leave out funds only where it has confirmed that those funds are not covered deposits, so exclusions must be limited to confirmed non-covered amounts rather than assumptions [#SRC:95405e3eada2b4e1].
source_text: Depositor Protection 43 sets out the PRA’s rule for calculating the FSCS tariff base for deposit-takers (the Class A tariff base). Depositor Protection 43.2 requires firms to do this calculation on the basis of covered deposits from the SCV file. Depositor Protection 43.1 requires firms to include the total balance of deposits in any account which holds funds to which the account holder is not absolutely entitled, or which are safeguarded funds, under the rules. Any funds which the firm has confirmed are not covered deposits may be excluded.
target_text: The class A tariff base calculation must be made on the basis of the information that the firm would have to include in its single customer views . The information must be of the extent and standard required if the firm was preparing the single customer view in accordance with the SCV requirements as at the valuation date for the tariff base.

question: When a ring-fenced body enters into a transaction with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate, how must it ensure the transaction terms meet the arm’s length requirement, and to what extent may the firm rely on compliance with existing regulatory requirements and OCIR record-keeping to evidence and document the relevant intragroup dependencies and arrangements for PRA review?
gold_answer: A ring-fenced body must ensure that any transaction it enters into with a member of its group that is not a ring-fenced affiliate is conducted only on arm’s length terms, so the pricing and other terms should be set and supported as if agreed between independent parties [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c]. In meeting this obligation, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations for intragroup outsourcing arrangements, including where those arrangements are subject to requirements in Operational Continuity and the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook; such compliance may also mean those banks meet certain expectations relevant to intragroup outsourcing, including expectations connected to business continuity and exit planning [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document intragroup dependencies, provided the relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request [#SRC:085af7075bdc3067]. Together, these materials can help a firm demonstrate that intragroup arrangements and dependencies are understood and documented while the ring-fenced body still adheres to the arm’s length transaction requirement [#TGT:a425bb0ba554003c].
source_text: Where relevant, firms may be able to leverage compliance with existing requirements in other areas of regulation to help meet their regulatory obligations in respect of their intragroup outsourcing arrangements. For instance, for some banks, intragroup outsourcing arrangements may be subject to the requirements in Operational Continuity Chapter 4 and Chapters 9 and 12 in the Ring-Fenced Bodies Part of the PRA Rulebook. Compliance with these requirements may also mean those banks meet certain expectations in this SS in respect of intragroup outsourcing arrangements (for instance, in respect of business continuity and exit plans (see Chapter 10 )). The PRA also expects firms to consider whether they can leverage elements of their operational continuity in resolution (OCIR) record-keeping to identify and document their intragroup dependencies, as long as relevant information is clear and readily available to the PRA upon request. 23
target_text: A ring-fenced body must enter into a transaction with a member of its group which is not a ring-fenced affiliate only on arm’s length terms.

question: For assets with contractually bounded but uncertain timing of cash flows, how should a firm determine whether it may treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and what portfolio-level limit applies to the MA benefit created by that HP cash flow proportion?
gold_answer: Where a firm is considering assets whose cash-flow timing is uncertain but bounded (eg, where redemption or repayment timing can vary within contractual bounds), the firm should assess whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and can be demonstrated not to present a material risk to the quality of matching. In the SS, assets that meet the relevant criteria and for which firms can demonstrate no material risk to matching quality are defined as “assets with HP cash flows” [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. The SOURCE indicates that, if the assets meet the HP cash flow criteria, firms may include them in the MA portfolio as part of a limited proportion permitted for such assets, rather than relying solely on a case-by-case assessment against the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. In applying this permission, the firm must also observe the aggregate portfolio constraint: the proportion of the MA portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: If an Institution is making the listed credit risk disclosures under the CRR, what does it have to say about its risk management objectives and policies, and what table and instructions does it have to follow?
gold_answer: If the Institution is producing the particular set of disclosures that are identified as being required for credit risk of the CRR, those disclosures are within a defined scope that must be prepared in accordance with the Table UK CRA of Annex XV and the relevant instructions in Annex XVI [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2]. For disclosures in that context, Institutions shall disclose their risk management objectives and policies for each separate category of risk, and this includes the risks referred to in this Title [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15]. So, when the Institution is addressing the scoped credit risk disclosures, it must include information describing its objectives and policies for managing risk, and it must do so in a way that is broken out by each separate risk category rather than being a single undifferentiated description. At the same time, the Institution must ensure the disclosure is structured and completed in line with the specified table and the related instructions, because those materials govern how the required credit risk disclosures are to be made [#SRC:ca610bab35052fa2] while still satisfying the obligation to disclose objectives and policies by risk category [#TGT:dedbe720c755ba15].

question: If you need to check whether the PRA has formally put certain EU Guidelines into effect after the implementation period, what should you note about the PRA’s position and what date should you tie it to?
gold_answer: You should note that, according to the Statement of Policy (SoP) on the “Interpretation of EU Guidelines and Recommendations: Bank of England and PRA approach after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU,” the PRA has not formally implemented the relevant Guidelines that came into force after the implementation period [#SRC:64fc82fb669b5a5f]. You should also tie that note to the SoP reference date provided in the related citation information, which is December 2020, and keep the associated link as evidence of which SoP is being relied upon [#TGT:66acc6070f5817e8]. Using both points together makes your compliance record clearer: it shows (1) the PRA’s stated approach to Guidelines that became effective after the implementation period, and (2) the specific dated SoP reference you used when reaching that conclusion. This helps ensure your internal analysis is consistent and traceable to the cited SoP reference date.

question: Where the Bank and PRA provide links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations for SoP purposes, what must firms and FMIs do in relation to other Guidelines and Recommendations (including those from predecessor committees to the ESAs) that are outside the linked list, and what are the limits on relevance for ESMA updates issued after the transition period?
gold_answer: Firms and FMIs should not treat the linked ESMA materials as the full universe of potentially applicable guidance. The appendices’ lists are described as not exhaustive, and the text gives a specific example that Guidelines and Recommendations made by predecessor committees to the ESAs are not included; nevertheless, firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with such materials unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]. At the same time, the SoP frames the scope of the ESMA materials it points to: it provides links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period, and it states that changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations and new Guidelines and Recommendations issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for SoP purposes [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024]. The Bank and PRA also acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials, reinforcing that the SoP’s linkage is a scoped reference point rather than an exhaustive compliance inventory [#TGT:332c541cadcf1024] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0].
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to ESMA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by ESMA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge ESMA as the source of these materials.

question: If an institution has to work out risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs, can it set the exposure value to zero for some collateral exposures, and when does that apply if a CCP or clearing member becomes insolvent?
gold_answer: The institution must calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs by summing the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs (calculated under the specified paragraphs) and then multiplying that total by the risk weight determined under the specified paragraph [#SRC:99cd1305ee2e0e40]. Separately, the institution may, as a derogation, assign an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for assets it has posted as collateral to a CCP or to a clearing member, but only if those collateral assets are bankruptcy remote when insolvency occurs [#TGT:3efc66c18754eca4]. The insolvency trigger is not limited to the CCP itself: the condition is met if the CCP, the clearing member, or one or more other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, provided the posted collateral remains bankruptcy remote in that scenario. In effect, the required CCP trade-exposure calculation uses exposure values, and the permission allows certain qualifying collateral-related exposure values to be reduced to zero before they feed into the summed amount.
source_text: An institution shall calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts for its trade exposures with CCPs for the purposes of Article 92(3) as the sum of the exposure values of its trade exposures with CCPs, calculated in accordance with paragraphs 2 and 3 of this Article, multiplied by the risk weight determined in accordance with paragraph 1 of this Article.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 1 , where assets posted as collateral to a CCP or a clearing member are bankruptcy remote in the event that the CCP, the clearing member or one or more of the other clients of the clearing member becomes insolvent, an institution may attribute an exposure value of zero to the counterparty credit risk exposures for those assets.

question: How must a firm demonstrate to the PRA that the methods and assumptions used in its internal model adhere to the Statistical Quality Standards principles, while also ensuring the internal model’s probability distribution forecast calculation meets the required compliance scope?
gold_answer: A firm must do two linked things: (1) ensure its internal model—specifically including the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it—meets the defined compliance scope, and (2) be able to demonstrate to the PRA that it complies with the relevant Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) principles governing the methods and assumptions used in the internal model. The operational compliance requirement is that the internal model and, in particular, the probability distribution forecast calculation, complies with 11.2 to 11.13, which sets the concrete compliance span the firm must satisfy and be able to point to in its governance and model operation [#TGT:3ed819cc35a6fc9d]. In parallel, the SQS for internal models set out requirements on the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to, and the firm’s compliance with those requirements must be evidenced to the PRA, meaning the firm must maintain and provide appropriate evidence demonstrating adherence rather than relying on unsupported assertions [#SRC:f9ebadff53a4bf82].
source_text: The Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) for internal models in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 11 and Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 16.2 set out requirements on the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to. Compliance with those requirements must be evidenced to the PRA.
target_text: A firm must ensure that its internal model and, in particular, the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it, complies with 11.2 to 11.13 .

question: When assets with HP cash flows are included in a firm’s MA portfolio, what must the firm do to ensure that additional risks arising from cash flow variability and uncertainty in cash flow timing or amount are fully reflected in the FS, and what documentation is expected to evidence that these risks have been sufficiently captured?
gold_answer: Where assets with HP cash flows are included in a firm’s MA portfolio, the firm must treat them as introducing additional risks and therefore apply increases to the FS to provision for those additional risks [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. In doing so, the firm must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for each source, rather than relying on a generic adjustment [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. The firm should also consider any additional risks that arise specifically from sources of cash flow variability and ensure those risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, using the relevant guidance referenced in the source passage [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. To evidence that the FS additions and allowances are complete and appropriate, the PRA expects the firm to document the details of the identified sources of uncertainty and explain how it has allowed for them within the FS approach applied to the MA portfolio [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. This combined approach links the identification of variability-driven risks to concrete FS additions and a documented rationale demonstrating sufficient capture [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6].
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: Assets with HP cash flows are likely to introduce additional risks into firms’ MA portfolios and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required (in accordance with Matching Adjustment 4.16 ) to provision for these additional risks. As required by Chapter 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part , firms must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for these. The PRA expects firms to document details of these sources of uncertainty and how they have allowed for them.

question: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the requirements must be applied at the level of the group with any needed adjustments, what does a firm have to do to make sure its risk-management system works for the group as well as for the firm itself?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the scope text says the listed requirements apply at the level of the group, with any necessary changes [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that situation, a firm must ensure its risk-management obligation is implemented in a way that is effective at group level, not just within a single entity boundary [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Specifically, the firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system that includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that operate continuously and can identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks both at an individual level and at an aggregated level, including how those risks depend on each other [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Applying the requirements “with any necessary changes” at group level means the firm should adapt how it structures and runs those strategies, processes, and reporting procedures so they can capture and communicate risk information across the group, while still meeting the continuous and multi-level risk coverage required of a firm [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: If a firm updates the statement of responsibilities record for a key function holder to keep it current, what must the firm do to ensure the updated record is properly executed, and which persons must sign?
gold_answer: The firm’s obligation has two linked components: it must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, and it must ensure that the record is properly signed when created and whenever it is updated [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Specifically, the record and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. Accordingly, when the firm updates the record to keep it current, it is not sufficient merely to revise the content; the firm must also obtain signatures on the updated version from both required signatories. This ensures that the key function holder confirms the updated statement of responsibilities and that an appropriate representative of the firm also attests to the updated record. The requirement applies to each updated version, so the firm should treat every update as requiring renewed execution by the key function holder and the firm’s appropriate representative, aligning the ongoing “up-to-date” maintenance duty with a continuing sign-off control [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: What must an insurer do to make sure its risk monitoring metrics help set and track any liquidity buffer(s), so it can still pay liabilities when due in normal and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer must ensure its risk monitoring metrics are used to support how it sets up and maintains any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, because those metrics are intended to underpin the establishment of the buffer and related monitoring [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352]. At the same time, the insurer has to hold and manage assets so its investment portfolio remains liquid and so it can meet obligations as they fall due, which includes considering total liquidity needs and monitoring the level of liquid assets [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. This requires the insurer to maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets (a liquidity buffer) that is sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and to be able to do so in both benign and stressed conditions [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. Therefore, the metrics should be structured to track liquid assets and inform whether the liquidity buffer remains adequate over time, rather than being separate from liquidity management, because they are used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352].
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: When setting downturn parameters for UK mortgage portfolios, how must a firm align its downturn PPGD estimates with its downturn LGD rating-system assumptions on property value declines, including the minimum house price deflation floor and the reference point for peak-to-downturn reductions?
gold_answer: A firm must ensure its downturn PPGD estimates appropriately reflect economic downturn conditions and are consistent with a fall in property values driven by house price deflation, applying a minimum deflation assumption that is not lower than 25% from the previous peak price and not lower than 5% from the current price [#SRC:12e0a6fed4bfdc7e]. In parallel, when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios, the PRA expects the firm’s rating systems to assume an average reduction in property sales prices of 40% from the peak price prior to the market downturn as an appropriate reference point, and to treat that reduction as capturing both market value decline and a distressed forced sale discount [#TGT:5bb0579cf870e51b]. The firm should therefore calibrate its downturn PPGD and downturn LGD assumptions so they are mutually consistent: the PPGD downturn property-value fall must at least meet the PRA’s deflation floors, while the LGD framework should be anchored to the PRA’s 40% peak-to-downturn sales-price reduction reference point and incorporate the forced-sale component described by the PRA. This alignment is required to ensure the downturn property-value assumptions used across estimation and rating systems are coherent and appropriately conservative.
source_text: The PRA expects firms to ensure that PPGD estimates appropriately reflect economic downturn conditions. The PRA expects (as in paragraphs 13.8 and 13.9 above) downturn PPGD estimates to be consistent with a fall in the value of property due to house price deflation not lower than 25% from the previous peak price, and not lower than 5% from the current price.
target_text: The PRA believes that an average reduction in property sales prices of 40% from their peak price, prior to the market downturn, forms an appropriate reference point when assessing downturn LGD for UK mortgage portfolios and expects a firm’s rating systems to assume a reduction consistent with this. This reduction captures both a fall in the value of the property due to market value decline as well as a distressed forced sale discount. The PRA expects the assumption for the fall in the value of the property due to house price deflation not to be lower than 25%.

question: If Institutions adjust exposures for trading book and non-trading book items, what breakdown of the prudent valuation adjustment must they prepare (by risk type and separately for each book), and how does this support the requirement that all fair-valued positions follow prudent valuation standards and reach an appropriate level of certainty?
gold_answer: Institutions must be able to show, for adjusted exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book, how the prudent valuation adjustment is built up from its constituent elements. This means preparing a breakdown of the amounts of those constituent elements by type of risks, and also presenting the total of the constituent elements separately for trading book positions and for non-trading book positions [#SRC:2523899445035439]. This breakdown is not just a formatting exercise; it should be used to evidence that Institutions have applied prudent valuation standards to all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, as required, and that the prudent valuation of trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty in light of the dynamic nature of those positions, prudential soundness, and the way capital requirements operate for both trading and fair-valued non-trading positions [#TGT:fab620639def0122]. By tying the risk-type components and book-level totals to the positions in scope, Institutions can demonstrate both coverage (all relevant positions are subject to the standards) and the intended certainty outcome.
source_text: (e) for exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book that are adjusted in accordance with Article 34 and Article 105 , a breakdown of the amounts of the constituent elements of an institution's prudent valuation adjustment, by type of risks, and the total of constituent elements separately for the trading book and non-trading book positions;
target_text: Institutions shall ensure that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value.

question: Who counts as a person indebted to a society on a land-secured loan, and how does that connect to when a society or subsidiary undertaking may use derivative investments to reduce how much it (or a connected undertaking) is affected by changes in a borrower’s creditworthiness?
gold_answer: A person fits the definition if they are indebted to a society in respect of a loan that is fully secured on land, or, where the Rules so provide, substantially secured on land [#TGT:7856ac9ac9cb1882]. That matters because the permission on derivative investments is framed around limiting exposure to specified changes, including changes in the creditworthiness of any borrower(s) [#SRC:bf19a4f593cb137a]. So, if the society is considering derivatives to manage the risk that a borrower’s ability to repay deteriorates, it should first confirm the borrower is indebted to the society under a qualifying land-secured loan as described in the definition. If that condition is met, the permission supports using derivative investments to limit the extent to which the society, its subsidiary undertaking, or a connected undertaking will be affected by that borrower creditworthiness change. The same permission also covers limiting impacts from interest rates, exchange rates, and certain price indices, but the borrower-creditworthiness link is the key connection to the defined land-secured indebtedness category.
source_text: (b) those which allow a society or subsidiary undertaking to use derivative investments in order to limit the extent to which it, or a connected undertaking, will be affected by changes in interest rates, exchange rates, any index of retail prices, any index of residential property prices, any index of the prices of securities, or the creditworthiness of any borrower(s). 2
target_text: 2. A person who is indebted to a society in respect of a loan fully, or where the Rules so provide, substantially secured on land.

question: When exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book are adjusted, what must Institutions produce to evidence prudent valuation compliance—specifically, what breakdown of the prudent valuation adjustment is required by risk type and by book, and how must that reporting align with the obligation that all fair-valued trading and non-trading book positions are subject to prudent valuation standards and achieve an appropriate degree of certainty?
gold_answer: Institutions must connect their prudent valuation governance and reporting so that, where exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book are adjusted, they can present a clear breakdown of the amounts making up the institution’s prudent valuation adjustment. That breakdown must identify the constituent elements by type of risks and must also show the total of those constituent elements separately for trading book positions and for non-trading book positions [#SRC:2523899445035439]. This reporting obligation sits within, and should be used to demonstrate, the broader requirement that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value are subject to the applicable prudent valuation standards, and that the prudent valuation of trading book positions in particular achieves an appropriate degree of certainty given the dynamic nature of those positions, prudential soundness considerations, and the role and operation of capital requirements for both trading and fair-valued non-trading positions [#TGT:fab620639def0122]. In practice, Institutions should ensure the breakdown is consistent with how positions are classified between books and how fair-valued positions are brought within the prudent valuation standards, so the risk-type components and book-level totals support the required certainty objective.
source_text: (e) for exposures from the trading book and the non-trading book that are adjusted in accordance with Article 34 and Article 105 , a breakdown of the amounts of the constituent elements of an institution's prudent valuation adjustment, by type of risks, and the total of constituent elements separately for the trading book and non-trading book positions;
target_text: Institutions shall ensure that all trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value shall be subject to the standards for prudent valuation specified in this Article and in Chapter 4 of the Trading Book (CRR) Part of the PRA Rulebook. Institutions shall in particular ensure that the prudent valuation of their trading book positions achieves an appropriate degree of certainty having regard to the dynamic nature of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value, the demands of prudential soundness and the mode of operation and purpose of capital requirements in respect of trading book positions and non-trading book positions measured at fair value.

question: For purposes of applying the permitted asset exposure limits, how should an Authorised Person determine whether a land holding falls within the defined 5% land exposure category, particularly where a proper valuation assigns an aggregate value to a piece of land or multiple pieces of land (or interests in them) that exceeds the sum of separate valuations?
gold_answer: The permitted asset exposure limits are defined by reference to the limits that are set out elsewhere, and an Authorised Person should treat those limits as the governing framework for what is permitted in relation to asset exposure [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187]. Within that framework, a specific land-related exposure category is defined as 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (including one or more interests in such pieces of land) where, in the most recent proper valuation, an aggregate value is ascribed to the relevant pieces of land that is greater than the aggregate of the value of each piece of land or interest valued separately [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a]. Practically, this means the compliance assessment must (i) identify whether the asset exposure is to a “piece of land” (or multiple pieces, or interests), (ii) confirm that the valuation used is the most recent proper valuation, and (iii) test whether the valuation methodology produces an aggregate value that exceeds the sum of separate valuations. If those definitional conditions are met, the relevant quantitative limit to apply for that land exposure category is 5%, and it must be applied as part of the permitted asset exposure limits framework [#SRC:4a2c6b4a1519f187] [#TGT:e0fdde5fe1fac33a].
source_text: The permitted asset exposure limits are those set out in 28.2 to 28.23 .
target_text: 5% for a piece of land or a number of pieces of land (or one or more interests in such pieces of land) to which in the most recent proper valuation of such pieces of land an aggregate value is ascribed which is greater than the aggregate of the value of each of such pieces of land or interests valued separately.

question: When deciding what would generally be expected to be written down, what does the law treat as an excluded liability for amounts secured on property, and how does the PRA expect liabilities secured by floating charges to be handled in the creditor hierarchy?
gold_answer: To decide what would generally be expected to be written down, you need to combine the legal definition of excluded liabilities for secured amounts with the PRA’s stated approach to write-down plans. Legally, an amount secured on property is treated as an excluded liability, but there is an important exception: if the security is a charge that, as created, was a floating charge, that secured amount is not treated as excluded on that basis (Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA) [#TGT:8a41e3fa3a9296cc]. The PRA then explains how this plays out in practice: it recognises that liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities and may therefore be written down, and it links this to avoiding an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors who often have floating charges but are contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority) [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96]. As a result, where floating-charge liabilities are not subordinated in that way, the PRA says they would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, following the creditor hierarchy [#SRC:3ab0329fffa4af96].
source_text: The PRA anticipates that write-down plans will broadly respect the creditor hierarchy in order to ‘lead to a better outcome for the insurer’s policyholders and other creditors (taken as a whole) than not making the order.’ 7 The PRA also recognises that while liabilities secured by floating charges are not excluded liabilities, 8 and may therefore be written-down, this is intended to ‘avoid creating an inappropriate and unintended priority for inward reinsurance creditors, who are often granted a floating charge but contractually subordinated to rank alongside direct policyholders (who have a statutory priority)’. 9 Accordingly, liabilities secured by floating charges which are not subordinated in this way would generally be expected to be written down only after lower-ranking liabilities, in accordance with the creditor hierarchy.
target_text: 8. Section 377B(1)(d) of FSMA treats ‘an amount secured on property of any kind, other than an amount secured by a charge which, as created, was a floating charge’ as an excluded liability (the term ‘floating charge’ is then defined in section 377B(2) of FSMA).

question: If identity checks were not done under the anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, what must insolvency practitioners consider about their objectives and responsibilities, and how can the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court help complete identity verification to decide FSCS protection eligibility?
gold_answer: If identity verification has not been carried out in line with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements before the firm’s compensation date, the PRA indicates that the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court is allowed to facilitate identity verification for the purpose of determining whether someone is eligible for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection [#SRC:eb355065b8865baf]. At the same time, insolvency practitioners should consider their actions in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009 [#TGT:02363a43a51fdf7b]. Putting these together, the practitioner should not ignore the missing identity checks: they can use the permitted facilitation route to complete verification needed for the eligibility decision, but they must do so while keeping their broader objectives and responsibilities in view. In other words, the permission explains what the court-appointed insolvency practitioner can do to address a verification gap, and the obligation explains the lens through which insolvency practitioners should evaluate and carry out that step as part of their role.
source_text: In the event that identity verification has not been carried out in accordance with the relevant anti-money laundering requirements referred to in Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) ahead of the firm’s compensation date, the PRA considers that Depositor Protection 2.2(4)(f) would allow the relevant insolvency practitioner appointed by the court to facilitate the identity verification for the purposes of determining eligibility for FSCS (Financial Services Compensation Scheme) protection. 2
target_text: 2. Insolvency practitioners should consider in line with the insolvency practitioner’s objectives and responsibilities under Section 99 of the Banking Act 2009.

question: When updating the insurer’s liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, what governance and prudential risk management elements must an insurer have in place to ensure the update is aligned with its required system of governance and information flows to management or the board?
gold_answer: When an insurer updates its liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies, it should do so within the framework of the effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems it is required to establish [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. Practically, the update should be anchored to the insurer’s risk appetite or tolerance for risk, and supported by a defined process to identify, measure, and monitor risk so that liquidity-related risks are assessed consistently and the strategy and policies remain coherent with the insurer’s overall risk approach [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. The insurer must also ensure it has appropriate systems to convey relevant information arising from the liquidity strategy and policy update to management or the board, so that decision-makers receive the necessary inputs and oversight can be exercised effectively [#TGT:e007010cf752bc53]. In this context, the liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies are specifically described as being used for update purposes, reinforcing that the insurer should treat liquidity strategy and policy maintenance as an ongoing governance activity rather than a one-off exercise [#SRC:8cda5a0f7fa9c1dd].
source_text: used to update the insurer’s liquidity risk management strategy and relevant policies (elaborated on in Chapter 2 );
target_text: Conditions Governing Business Chapters 2 and 3 , supplemented by Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance Chapters 2 , 3 and 7 require an insurer to establish an effective system of governance and prudential risk management systems. An insurer is required to have a risk appetite or tolerance for risk, a process to identify, measure, and monitor risk and appropriate systems to convey information to management or the board.

question: Which firms must report the operational risk Pillar 2 data, and how do the completion requirements for the specified operational risk data items interact with the exception where the same information has already been provided to the PRA through another channel such as the STDF programme, including the expectation that the data accompany ICAAP submissions?
gold_answer: The obligation applies to two categories of firms: (i) a significant firm and (ii) any firm that is not significant but that has permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach. For these firms, the operational risk Pillar 2 reporting requirement means they must provide the operational risk data items, and specifically must complete the operational risk data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075, as part of meeting the PRA’s operational risk data expectations [#TGT:749a0bb00a1a5a55]. However, both passages recognise an exception intended to avoid duplicate reporting: the firm does not need to submit the relevant data item where the same data have already been reported to the PRA by other means, including where the PRA has already collected the information via firms participating in the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme [#SRC:d4df391897643422]. Where the exception does not apply, firms are required to submit the data with their ICAAP submissions, and the PRA may also request some firms that are not significant to report the same data, notifying them in advance of ICAAP submission [#SRC:d4df391897643422].
source_text: The PRA already collects information on operational risk historical losses from firms participating in the Stress Testing Data Framework (STDF) programme. All significant firms and firms with AMA permission must report the data contained in the operational risk Pillar 2 data items in accordance with Reporting Pillar 2, 2.3 , unless those data have already been submitted as part of the STDF programme. Firms are required to submit the data with their ICAAP submissions. ‘Significant firm’ means a deposit-taker or PRA-designated investment firm whose size, interconnectedness, complexity and business type give it the capacity to cause significant disruption to the UK financial system (and through that to economic activity more widely) by failing or carrying on its business in an unsafe manner. The PRA may also request some firms that are not significant to report the same data and will notify the firms accordingly in advance of their submitting an ICAAP document.
target_text: A significant firm and any firm that is not significant but that has permission from the PRA to use the Advanced Measurement Approach must complete the data items FSA072, FSA073, FSA074 and FSA075 for operational risk, unless the data required in that data item has already been reported to the PRA by other means.

question: If a firm has dependants with exposure to the same type of assets, how do you work out the dependant exposure and what do you then have to do to the firm’s own exposure amount?
gold_answer: You must treat the dependant exposure as something that is calculated in a structured way, not estimated informally. Specifically, for each dependant, you calculate its exposure by applying the same provisions used for a firm’s exposure calculation, and you do so as if that dependant were a firm to which those provisions apply, even if it is not actually within scope as a firm [#TGT:d0975ff530ed6e30]. After you have those dependant exposure results, you then adjust the firm’s own exposure figure: the amount of the firm’s exposure to the relevant assets (as determined under the same provisions) must be increased by an additional amount that represents the exposure, if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description [#SRC:250709f3ef53e2f6]. So the sequence is: calculate the firm’s exposure under the provisions, calculate each dependant’s exposure using the same method-as-if-a-firm approach, and then add an increment to the firm’s exposure equal to the dependant exposure amount(s), but only where dependant exposure exists.
source_text: Subject to 23.2 and 23.3 , the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with 18 to 22 must be increased by an amount representing the exposure , if any, of the firm’s dependants to assets of that description.
target_text: For the purposes of 23.1 , the exposure of each dependant must be calculated by applying 18 to 22 to that dependant as if it were a firm to which those provisions apply (whether it is or not).

question: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK, including where traders have been relocated to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK, what must a UK trading bank or international bank carrying on activities in the UK do to evidence appropriate control and ensure effective UK oversight of the resulting remote books, including any orphan or shared books?
gold_answer: Where a firm has arrangements involving 100% remote booking into the UK—whether arising from relocation of traders to an overseas office or entity that remotely manages risk into the UK or otherwise—the arrangements must be treated as higher-risk and subjected to greater scrutiny, supported by high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled [#SRC:b1b392f95f91bdcf]. In parallel, any UK trading bank or international bank (subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings must ensure there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, with particular focus where there is no UK based trader covering the book (orphan books) [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Where the operating model includes shared books or desks with a mix of local and remote traders, the bank must clearly define these in the booking taxonomy and identify the portion of risk remote-booked into the UK so it can be subject to remote booking controls [#TGT:c57c2301e31ab615]. Taken together, the heightened evidencing expectation for 100% remote booking should be met through demonstrable UK oversight and clear taxonomy and control of remote-booked risk.
source_text: c) Whether the change may lead to traders being relocated to an overseas office or entity with the role of remotely managing risk into the UK; where the firm plans an increase in remote trading, the allocation of the number and relative seniority of traders should normally be broadly aligned with the proportion of activity managed across the locations. Where the size of business undertaken in the second location is negligible, this is unlikely to be sufficient justification to warrant the splitting of a desk. Any existing arrangements where there is 100% remote booking into the UK, irrespective of whether they result from a relocation or not, should be subjected to greater scrutiny, and require high levels of evidence that they are appropriately controlled (and see 4.25P ).
target_text: Any UK trading bank or international bank (whether a subsidiary or branch) carrying on activities in the UK that receives remote bookings should ensure that there is substantive UK oversight of these remote books as a risk mitigant, and particularly in cases where there is no UK based trader covering the book (often called ‘orphan books’). ‘Shared’ books or desks, where there is a mix of local and remote traders, should be clearly defined in the booking taxonomy and the portion of the risk remote-booked into the UK is expected to be identified and subject to remote booking controls.

question: For purposes of the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement setting expectations on banks’ model risk management, which types of firms fall within scope, and which categories are expressly outside scope despite the use of the term “banks” in the title?
gold_answer: The Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement is framed as setting out the PRA’s expectations for banks’ model risk management (MRM), and it also makes clear that the PRA considers model risk to be a risk in its own right [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d]. Read together with the scope clarification, the expectations are not limited only to entities commonly described as “banks” in ordinary language: the scope includes banks, building societies, and designated investment firms [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. At the same time, the use of “banks” in the title is specifically intended to signal an exclusion: the expectations do not apply to insurers or reinsurers [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa]. Accordingly, when applying the PRA’s MRM expectations, firms should determine applicability by reference to the stated scope categories (banks, building societies, and designated investment firms) and should treat insurers and reinsurers as out of scope, even though the statement’s title uses the term “banks” [#SRC:af03f7cbf472c97d] [#TGT:c120c182f73a34aa].
source_text: This Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) supervisory statement (SS) sets out the PRA’s expectations for banks’ 1 model risk management (MRM). The PRA considers model risk as a risk in its own right.
target_text: 1. While the scope of this SS includes banks, building societies, and designated investment firms, the term ‘banks’ is used in the title to make it clear that the expectations do not apply to insurers or reinsurers.

question: Where a transferor society and a transferee society propose to use bonus payments to equalise the reserves brought into the combined society (including any scenario where both sets of members may receive a bonus and the equalisation level could be set below the transferee society’s capital ratio if prudent), how must member approval be obtained through the Merger Resolutions, and how does the prescribed limit on total gross cost affect which societies’ Merger Resolutions must include that approval?
gold_answer: Bonus payments may be used to equalise the reserves that a transferor society and a transferee society bring to the combined society, including (if thought desirable) paying a bonus to members of the transferee society so that the combined society’s reserves are equalised at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio, but only where it is prudent to do so [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]. However, implementing any such bonus arrangement requires members’ approval as part of the Merger Resolutions [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. The way that approval must be embedded depends on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) measured against the prescribed limit: if the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval need only appear in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8], even if the underlying rationale for the bonus is reserve equalisation permitted on prudence grounds [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6].
source_text: A bonus may, for example, be paid to the members of a transferor society with a higher capital ratio than the transferee society so as to equalise the reserves which both bring to the combined society. If it is thought desirable also to pay a bonus to the members of the transferee society, then the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the capital ratio of the transferee society, but only if it is prudent to do so. The statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) (ie without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery) is within the prescribed limit, then approval for it need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If we are looking at PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024, what does it mean that Appendix 1 is a past version, and how does that fit with the PRA saying it has described other versions before and that the tests shown below are the latest?
gold_answer: For PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024, the reference to a “Past version of Appendix 1” signals that the Appendix 1 material you are using is an earlier version tied to that pre‑31/12/2024 context [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620]. Separately, the PRA has explained that, in earlier communications with firms, it described other versions of these tests, and that the tests presented “below” are the most recent versions [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472]. Putting those points together, you should treat the pre‑31/12/2024 Appendix 1 content as historical and understand that it may not match the latest version of the tests. You should also be aware that there may have been multiple prior versions communicated over time, not just the one captured in the past Appendix 1 reference. When you write up your compliance evidence for the pre‑31/12/2024 period, make sure you label the version you used as the past Appendix 1 version and distinguish it from the most recent versions the PRA refers to, so there is no confusion about which test set applied to which period [#SRC:64a39e6c30fff620] [#TGT:f7e0497cce253472].
source_text: Past version of Appendix 1 : PRA Matching Tests before 31/12/2024

question: Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies and the listed requirements are applied at the level of the group with any necessary changes, how must a firm implement its obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system, and what does that imply for identifying and reporting risks on both an individual and aggregated basis across the group?
gold_answer: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the scope provision requires that the specified requirements apply “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]. In that context, a firm’s obligation to establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system must be carried out in a way that functions at group level, not only for the firm viewed in isolation [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Practically, this means the firm’s strategies, processes, and reporting procedures must be capable of identifying, measuring, monitoring, managing, and reporting risks on a continuous basis in a manner that captures both (i) risks at an individual level and (ii) risks at an aggregated level, including the interdependencies among those risks, across the group as relevant [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. The “necessary changes” concept in the scope provision supports adapting the application of the listed requirements so the risk-management system’s design and reporting lines operate effectively at group level while still meeting the continuous, multi-level risk coverage required of a firm [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].
source_text: (1) Where 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the following requirements apply with any necessary changes at the level of the group : (1a) Conditions Governing Business 1A ; (a) Conditions Governing Business 2.2 to 2.6 ; (a1) Conditions Governing Business 2A.1 to 2A.6 ; (b) Conditions Governing Business 3 ; (b1) Conditions Governing Business 3A ; (c) Conditions Governing Business 4 ; (c1) Conditions Governing Business 4A ; (d) Conditions Governing Business 5 ; (e) Conditions Governing Business 6 ; (f) Conditions Governing Business 7 ; (f1) Conditions Governing Business 11A to 11F ; (g) Fitness and Propriety 2.1 to 2.3 , 4.1 , 4.3 and 4.4 ; (h) Allocation of Responsibilities 4 ; and (i) Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 , in accordance with 17.4 .
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the group treat own funds that are only eligible to cover the SCR of the related undertaking, and what quantitative cap applies to the amount of such own funds that may be included so that the group calculation does not rely on amounts beyond the related Solvency II undertaking’s SCR?
gold_answer: In the group solvency calculation, items that fall within the category described in the group-calculation rule must be excluded unless they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking concerned, and then only to the extent of that eligibility [#TGT:d68b868d9faa51ba]. This exclusion/limited-inclusion condition must be applied together with the quantitative constraint on inclusion of own funds: the sum of the own funds included under the relevant inclusion routes must not exceed the SCR of the related Solvency II undertaking [#SRC:d8e1f257c79a1b03]. Read together, the group must (i) start from a presumption of exclusion for the specified items in the group solvency calculation, (ii) allow inclusion only where and to the extent the items are eligible to cover the related undertaking’s SCR, and (iii) ensure that, even where inclusion is permitted, the aggregate amount of own funds included does not go beyond the related undertaking’s SCR. Operationally, this means the group should apply an eligibility screen first and then apply a hard cap at the related undertaking’s SCR to the total own funds it includes via those routes.

question: If a new DGS member has to work out its class A tariff base, how should it do the calculation, and when does it use a projected valuation of the business instead of something else?
gold_answer: A new DGS member is required to calculate its class A tariff base, so it must take an active step to determine that figure rather than leaving it unspecified [#SRC:f441f3fa763671cd]. The way the calculation is to be done is set by the procedural rule that, as the default position, A’s class A tariff base is calculated—when the calculation is needed—using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates [#TGT:7eeca38c43f8e855]. So, the member should start by checking whether the tariff base needs to be calculated in the particular situation (“where necessary”). If it does, the member should then base the tariff base on a projected valuation of the relevant business. The only time the member should not follow that projected-valuation approach is when the stated exception applies (“unless otherwise provided”), in which case the member would follow whatever alternative is provided for that exception. This ties the member’s obligation to calculate the tariff base to the specific method used to compute it.
source_text: A new DGS member must calculate its class A tariff base in accordance with 41.6 .
target_text: (1) Unless otherwise provided in (2), A’s class A tariff base is calculated, where necessary, using a projected valuation of the business to which the tariff relates

question: When calculating the solvency of a group, how must the participating undertaking reflect its interests in related undertakings, and how must data for related undertakings linked by a common management relationship be included notwithstanding other treatment of that data?
gold_answer: In calculating the solvency of a group, the participating undertaking must ensure that the calculation reflects the proportional share it holds in its related undertakings, so that the group solvency outcome is based on the participating undertaking’s proportionate interest rather than a full consolidation or other non-proportional approach [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc]. Consistently with that requirement, data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship must be included on a proportional-share basis, and this inclusion applies notwithstanding the otherwise applicable treatment referenced for that data [#SRC:477b207547388eb5]. Practically, this means the participating undertaking should identify which undertakings are “related undertakings” and which of those are linked by a common management relationship, then include the relevant data using one of the specified inclusion approaches, but always calibrated to the proportional share. The proportional share basis is the common thread: it governs both the group solvency calculation and the inclusion of data for commonly managed related undertakings, ensuring the same proportionality principle is applied across the calculation and the underlying data inputs [#SRC:477b207547388eb5] [#TGT:acc84032d208c7bc].
source_text: Notwithstanding point (4) of 11.1A data of related undertakings linked by a common management relationship shall be included in accordance with points (1), (3), (4), (5) or (6) of 11.1A on the basis of the proportional share as referred to in Chapter 8 .
target_text: The calculation of the solvency of a group must take account of the proportional share held by the participating undertaking in its related undertakings .

question: When an institution uses the standardised framework, how does the derogation for the requirements concerning descriptions of the economic value of equity affect what the institution must disclose about interest rate risk in its non-trading book activities, including impacts on both economic value of equity and net interest income?
gold_answer: Institutions are generally required to disclose specified quantitative and qualitative information about risks from potential changes in interest rates affecting both the economic value of equity and the net interest income of their non-trading book activities [#TGT:c4b6e2c4dc5015d9]. However, where an institution uses the standardised framework, a derogation applies such that the particular requirements that are set out for descriptions relating to the economic value of equity—namely those identified as points (c) and (e)(i) to (e)(iv)—do not apply to that institution [#SRC:f79420213b392d41]. Read together, this means the institution still has a disclosure obligation covering interest rate risk impacts on both economic value of equity and net interest income for its non-trading book activities, but it is not required to comply with the specific subset of requirements that would otherwise mandate certain descriptions relating to the economic value of equity. The practical effect is a scoped adjustment to the content of the economic value of equity-related descriptive elements within the broader interest rate risk disclosure package, limited to institutions that use the standardised framework.

question: If board members do not have to be technical experts on operational resilience, what does the PRA still expect the board to have so it can challenge senior management, and which named PRA Rulebook rule is pointed to for CRR firms?
gold_answer: Even where individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, the PRA still expects boards to make sure they have the appropriate management information, and that the board as a whole has enough knowledge, skills, and experience to challenge senior management constructively and to make informed decisions that affect operational resilience [#SRC:899315b848004882]. For CRR firms, the specific PRA Rulebook cross-reference identified is Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms) [#TGT:39817b585204e92e]. Putting these together, the practical message is that the board’s effectiveness on operational resilience should be evidenced through the management information it receives and uses, and through the board’s collective capability to question and test senior management’s approach, rather than through each director being a technical specialist. The Rule 5.2 reference provides the concrete rule label that is linked to this expectation for CRR firms [#SRC:899315b848004882] [#TGT:39817b585204e92e].
source_text: While individual board members are not required to be technical experts on operational resilience, the PRA expects boards to ensure that they have the appropriate management information. Boards should also collectively possess adequate knowledge, skills, and experience to provide constructive challenge to senior management and inform decisions that have consequences for operational resilience. 26
target_text: 26. Rule 5.2 in the General Organisational Requirements Part of the PRA Rulebook (CRR firms), Rule 2.7 in the Conditions Governing Business Part of the PRA Rulebook (Solvency II firms).

question: If a firm has assets where the cash-flow timing is not certain but is still within a contractual range, when can it treat them as assets with HP cash flows and include them in the MA portfolio, and how much MA benefit can that HP cash flow slice create overall?
gold_answer: If a firm holds assets with cash flows whose timing is uncertain but bounded (for example, where redemption or the start of repayments can vary within a contractually bounded period), the firm should consider whether those assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows and, if they do, it may include them in the MA portfolio within the limited proportion allowed for such assets [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The TARGET explains what “assets with HP cash flows” means in this SS: they are the assets meeting the relevant criteria that firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1]. This definition matters because it is the trigger for the portfolio treatment described in the SOURCE (including them as part of the permitted limited proportion) rather than only seeking case-by-case assessment under the fixed cash flow requirement [#SRC:e9aa8247582c38d4]. The firm must also apply the portfolio-level cap described in the TARGET: in aggregate, the proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, and it may be subject to additional safeguards to manage and mitigate added risks [#TGT:b4a5a68f305c3fd1].
source_text: The PRA is aware that some assets will contain cash flows where the timing is uncertain but is bounded, for example final redemption payments on callable bonds, or bonds where the timing at which repayments start can vary within a contractually bounded period. The PRA will assess firms’ applications to include such assets as meeting the fixed cash flow requirement on a case-by-case basis. Firms could also consider whether the assets meet the criteria for HP cash flows as set out in paragraphs 2.12A and 2.12D above and, if so, include them in the MA portfolio as part of the limited proportion permitted for these assets.
target_text: In this SS, the assets meeting the criteria referred to in paragraph 2.12A above (which firms can demonstrate do not present a material risk to the quality of matching (see Chapter 4 of this SS)) are referred to as assets with HP cash flows. The proportion of the portfolio with HP cash flows is limited in aggregate to creating 10% of the MA benefit for the MA portfolio, as set out in PRA Rule Matching Adjustment 5.2 , and may also be subject to additional safeguards in order to manage and mitigate the additional risks introduced into the MA portfolio (see paragraph 5.18 of this SS).

question: If the firm outsources a critical or important function to a service provider in the same group, what must the firm check in the written agreement, and what must it consider about its control or influence over the service provider?
gold_answer: The firm must address both the contract content and the group-relationship context. On the contract side, the firm must ensure the terms and conditions of the written agreement are consistent with the firm’s obligations under the relevant requirements identified in the source, meaning the agreement should not conflict with, or fall short of, what the firm is required to do [#SRC:21f32c39e40bb35a]. On the group-outsourcing side, where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group and the outsourcing concerns critical or important operational functions or activities, the firm must take into account how much it controls the service provider or how much it can influence the service provider’s actions [#TGT:0ed38a7a991d91b5]. Taken together, the firm should ensure the written agreement and the way it governs the outsourcing reflect both its underlying obligations and the practical realities of intra-group control or influence, so responsibilities and oversight are set appropriately for the arrangement.
source_text: A firm must ensure that the terms and conditions of the written agreement referred to in 7.5(3) are consistent with the firm’s obligations as provided for in 7.1 , 7.2 and 7.2A .
target_text: Where the firm and the service provider are members of the same group , the firm must, when outsourcing any critical or important operational functions or activities, take into account the extent to which the firm controls the service provider or has the ability to influence its actions.

question: When a firm is permitted not to follow certain compliance-related requirements because doing so would be disproportionate given the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, what must the firm still ensure so that the compliance function can discharge its responsibilities properly and independently?
gold_answer: A firm may be permitted not to comply with certain requirements where, in view of the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, compliance would not be proportionate, provided that the firm’s compliance function is, and continues to be, effective [#SRC:029ad42316e71977]. Even where that permission applies, the firm remains subject to an overarching obligation to ensure that the compliance function is able to discharge its responsibilities properly and independently [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2]. Read together, this means the firm cannot treat the proportionality-based non-compliance as a relaxation of the need for an effective compliance function; rather, it must maintain arrangements that support proper and independent performance of the compliance function’s responsibilities while also ensuring the function remains effective on an ongoing basis. The firm should therefore assess proportionality in light of its business and activities, and only rely on the permission if it can demonstrate continuing effectiveness of the compliance function alongside the required ability for that function to operate properly and independently [#SRC:029ad42316e71977] [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2].

question: When an institution acts as a clearing member for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, what must it do to determine the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP, and how must the resulting sum of own funds requirements for exposures to a QCCP arising from trade exposures and default fund contributions be constrained?
gold_answer: Where an institution acts as a clearing member, either for its own purposes or as a financial intermediary between a client and a CCP, it is required to calculate the own funds requirements for its exposures to a CCP in accordance with the prescribed approach for that calculation [#TGT:90f89b9de841e0ff]. In addition, for the purposes of the relevant calculation context, the institution must apply a limiting constraint to the aggregate outcome for certain QCCP-related components: specifically, the sum of the institution’s own funds requirements for its exposures to a QCCP that are due to trade exposures and default fund contributions is not permitted to exceed a cap. question: If a TWD firm wants to check whether it can produce the data the PRA expects under this SS, how do the PRA’s templates and instructions and Template A help it judge the required breadth and detail, especially for exit costs and liquidity flows?
gold_answer: A TWD firm can use the PRA’s templates and accompanying instructions as the main reference point for what the PRA would expect the firm to be able to produce under the SS, because those materials are described as providing a guide to the breadth and granularity of the required data outputs [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c]. Template A (Appendix 1) helps the firm make that expectation more concrete by showing the kind of data breadth and detail that should be available to demonstrate a specific capability: analysing exit costs and liquidity flows. In doing so, Template A highlights that the firm should be able to segment the balance sheet by method and price of exit, which implies the firm’s data production needs to support those breakdowns so the analysis can be performed in a structured way rather than at a single aggregated level [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8]. So, the firm should compare what it can currently produce against the PRA’s templates/instructions generally, and then use Template A as a focused check that it can produce sufficiently granular, segmented balance-sheet data to support exit-cost and liquidity-flow analysis as expected [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c] [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8].
