question: When applying the rule that sets the boundary for whether a deposit qualifies as an eligible deposit, what reasonable steps must a firm take to establish a local authority’s annual budget, and how must the firm treat the local authority if it cannot determine eligibility after taking those steps?
gold_answer: In determining whether a deposit falls within the scope of the rule that decides if it is an eligible deposit, a firm must apply the PRA’s expectation that it takes reasonable steps to ascertain a local authority’s annual budget, because that information is relevant to whether the local authority is eligible for the purposes of the eligibility determination [#TGT:02fb0fbf6939a082]. The firm may rely on a reasonable estimate of the annual budget provided by the local authority, including an estimate based on the previous year’s budget, as an acceptable means of meeting this expectation where direct confirmation is not available [#SRC:6c7186a4053377c4]. However, if after taking reasonable steps the firm is unable to determine whether the local authority is eligible, the firm must treat the local authority as a public authority for the purposes of applying the eligibility framework to the deposit [#SRC:6c7186a4053377c4]. This approach ensures the firm’s eligibility assessment is grounded in a documented attempt to obtain budget information while still providing a clear classification outcome when eligibility cannot be confirmed, so the deposit can be assessed consistently under the rule’s eligibility provisions [#TGT:02fb0fbf6939a082].

question: If a firm is estimating long-run PDs for a grade or pool, what does it need to do with the length of its data series, and how should it avoid just averaging its own past defaults or updating the estimate every year?
gold_answer: The firm should use a data series of appropriate length so it can produce a reasonable estimate of the long-run default rate, rather than relying on an arbitrarily short or convenient window [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a]. For PDs that are long-run averages of one-year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects the firm to estimate expected default rates over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, instead of simply taking the historic average of default rates the firm actually incurred over a period of years [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]. This means the “right” length is the one that helps capture that representative mix, not just the number of years on hand. The PRA also expects that the long-run estimate should be changed when there is reason to believe the current estimate is no longer accurate, but it should not be automatically updated to add each new year of experience, because those additional years may not be representative of the long-run average [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea]. So the firm should pick a data series length that supports a representative long-run view and update it only when accuracy is in doubt [#SRC:bbb89e949553ef1a] [#TGT:13e5135f24e80eea].

target_text: In order to estimate PDs that are long-run averages of one year default rates for obligor grades or pools, the PRA expects firms to estimate expected default rates for the grade/pool over a representative mix of good and bad economic periods, rather than simply taking the historic average of default rates actually incurred by the firm over a period of years. question: If a firm is going to issue CET1 or AT1, or change the terms of CET1 or AT1, when must it tell the PRA, and how is that different from the timing for Tier 2 under the PRA Rulebook’s pre-issuance vs post-notification approach?
gold_answer: For CET1 and AT1, a firm must notify the PRA ahead of time when it intends to issue the instrument or when it intends to amend or vary its terms, as long as the instrument will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds. The timing is at least one month before the intended date of the issuance or the intended date of the amendment or variation, and this applies whether the instrument is counted at solo, sub-consolidated, or group consolidated level (or any combination) [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]. This matches the PRA Rulebook description that CET1 and AT1 issuances require pre-issuance notification [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268]. Tier 2 is handled differently: instead of a one-month pre-notice, the firm must notify the PRA immediately after it issues a Tier 2 capital instrument, and immediately after it amends or varies the terms of a Tier 2 capital instrument, where it will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]. That immediate-after approach corresponds to the Rulebook’s post-notification requirement for Tier 2 issuances [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268].
source_text: Firms are generally required 6 to notify the PRA at least one month before the intended date of issuance or amendment or variation to the terms of each CET1 or AT1 capital instrument, and immediately after issuing or amending or varying the terms of each Tier 2 capital instrument, that will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds, either at solo, sub-consolidated or group consolidated level or any combination of these.
target_text: 6. Rules 7A to 7D of Definition of Capital Part of the PRA Rulebook require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances, and post-notification for Tier 2 issuances.

question: A notice says you may refer the matter to the Tribunal and explains how to do it. What does “Tribunal” mean here, and what happens if the Tribunal has been replaced by another body?
gold_answer: If a notice tells you that you have a right to have the matter referred and it also explains the procedure for making that referral, you need to understand what “Tribunal” means in that context. The definition makes clear that “Tribunal” is the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber). It also includes any successor body, meaning that if the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) is replaced or its role is taken over by another body, the term “Tribunal” covers that replacement. Putting the two together, the notice’s statement about your right to refer and the steps it gives for doing so should be treated as pointing you to the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) as the place to send the reference, unless there is a successor body, in which case the reference should go to that successor instead. This links the notice’s procedural guidance to the correct forum identified by the definition. [#SRC:a967680a6134e470] [#TGT:f7f54d793dfe546b]
source_text: The notice also gives an indication of any right to have the matter referred to the Tribunal 3 and the procedure for such a reference.
target_text: 3. ‘Tribunal’ means the Upper Tribunal (Tax and Chancery Chamber) or any successor body.

question: When the PRA is deciding if the Merger Resolutions vote really reflects what members think, what should the scrutineers report say about invalid votes (especially if there are many), and why does that matter even if turnout is low?
gold_answer: The PRA’s criterion is about whether the votes on the Merger Resolutions represent the views of the members, with the key concern being a merger approved by a small and unrepresentative vote [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97]. A low turnout by itself does not automatically mean the criterion is met; the PRA must look at turnout alongside other criteria and other factors that may have affected participation [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97]. In that context, if the number of invalid votes appears significant, the PRA would find it helpful for the scrutineers report to explain what went wrong in the process (any procedural difficulties) and to give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found invalid, rather than simply listing a number [#SRC:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]. This matters because the scrutineers report is one of the inputs the PRA considers on the conduct and counting of votes, including the number of and reasons for invalid proxy votes, which can help show whether members had adequate facilities and opportunity to vote and whether the recorded result is likely to reflect members’ views [#TGT:2dd0fc894f17de97].
source_text: The PRA would find it helpful if the scrutineers report would also comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant (see also paragraph 3.171 ).
target_text: This criterion requires the PRA to consider whether the votes on the Merger Resolutions do not represent the views of the members. The main mischief to which it appears to be directed is a merger approved by a small and unrepresentative vote. However, a very low turnout, of itself, does not necessarily mean that the criterion applies. It has to be considered in the context of the other criteria, and of any other factors which may have affected the turnout: for example, whether all the members entitled to vote were fully and clearly informed of the terms of the merger proposal and its consequences; whether the members were afforded adequate facilities and opportunity to cast their votes; and the scrutineers report on the conduct and counting of votes, including the number of, and reasons for, invalid proxy votes.

question: When the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a ‘UK trading bank’, how must the firm evidence senior management accountability for oversight of booking arrangements, and what approval consideration arises for parent or group-entity individuals who materially influence the firm’s UK regulated activities?
gold_answer: Where the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to a firm that falls within the described scope—namely, a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK or part of a UK-based group and that conducts investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas (referred to as ‘UK trading banks’)—the firm should treat those expectations as applicable in line with the stated delineation between expectations that apply to international banks alone and those that apply to international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. In that context, the PRA expects the firm to allocate responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record this appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities, so that accountability for booking-arrangements oversight is clearly documented [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. Separately, where individuals in the parent or in group entities exercise significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, the firm should assess whether it may be appropriate for those individuals to be approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), recognising that firms have applied for SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].
source_text: In addition, the sections on the PRA’s expectations of booking arrangements [ Chapter 4 ] also apply to all PRA-authorised banks and designated investment firms that are headquartered in the UK or are part of a group based in the UK, and have investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas. In this SS, these firms are denoted ‘UK trading banks’. These sections comprise paragraphs 4.1(d) , 4.20 , 4.23 , 4.25Y, 4.25AE , 5.14-5.16 and the Annex on Context and definitions. We make clear in the relevant sections where the expectations apply to international banks alone, and where they apply to international banks and UK trading banks. See paragraph 4.24B for a summary of the terminology used to describe the scope of application for the booking expectations.

question: If a firm is using transitional arrangements and the PRA is assessing its capital position until the end of 2023, what does IFRS 9 mean in this context, including when it was issued and when it became effective?
gold_answer: In this context, IFRS 9 is the accounting standard that sets the rules for accounting for financial instruments and replaces the earlier rules in International Accounting Standard (IAS) 39 [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]. The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary, and it will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for IFRS 9 until the end of 2023 where firms are using these arrangements [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7]. The definition details that IFRS 9 was issued in July 2014 and, following endorsement for use in the EU, is effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018 [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1]. Putting these together, when the PRA assesses a firm’s capital position under the IFRS 9 transitional arrangements through end-2023, the relevant accounting baseline is the IFRS 9 framework (issued July 2014; effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2018; replacing IAS 39) that governs financial instruments accounting [#SRC:ca2603599644f9a7] [#TGT:9d3a529207cb52b1].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to hold a larger buffer or strengthen their capital position where necessary based on other factors. These include, but are not limited to: the firm’s leverage ratio; Tier 1 and total capital ratios; risks associated with double leverage; and the extent to which potentially significant risks are not captured fully as part of the stress test. Until the end of 2023, the PRA will also assess firms’ capital positions under transitional arrangements for International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 9, 53 where firms are using these arrangements.

question: When determining the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, what must be done to ensure the best estimate calculation remains transparent and can be reviewed by a qualified expert, and how should the grouping decision be reflected in the calculation approach and outputs?
gold_answer: When assessing the appropriateness of any grouping of policies, the best estimate must still be calculated transparently and in a way that enables a qualified expert to review both the calculation method and the resulting outputs. This means the grouping approach cannot be treated as a purely administrative step; it must be integrated into the best estimate methodology so that an expert reviewer can understand how the grouping was selected, how it affects the calculation method, and how it influences the results. In practice, the calculation should be structured and documented so that the link between the grouping of policies and the best estimate is clear, including how the grouping is applied within the method and how the results “derive from it” under that grouping. The overall objective is that the grouping is demonstrably appropriate while the best estimate remains capable of independent expert review, with transparency over both method and outcomes as required [#TGT:d7e9f9c8806d968f] and with explicit consideration of the appropriateness of any grouping of policies [#SRC:454105ea3e8bfc14].
source_text: (b) the appropriateness of any grouping of policies in accordance with Technical Provisions - Further Requirements 19 ;

question: As part of BAU activities, what must a firm do to evidence its preparations for an orderly solvent exit, and how does that obligation apply even where solvent exit appears remote, alongside the separate requirement that applies once execution becomes a reasonable prospect?
gold_answer: A firm is expected to treat preparation for an orderly solvent exit as a standing BAU activity and to document that preparation by producing a solvent exit analysis that meets the PRA’s expectations for preparation. This preparation-focused analysis is not optional or contingent on the firm’s current view of likelihood; the expectations apply even where a solvent exit seems unlikely or distant, so the firm should still complete the analysis as part of its ongoing BAU arrangements [#TGT:ce7365f82f898e3e]. In parallel, the framework distinguishes preparation from execution: when and if the execution of a solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect for the firm, the firm should then produce a solvent exit execution plan, consistent with the PRA’s expectations for execution planning and for managing and monitoring the execution process [#SRC:005f99bdd705abe3]. Taken together, the firm should maintain BAU readiness through the solvent exit analysis, while also being prepared to transition to producing an execution plan once the execution trigger is met, ensuring continuity between preparation and execution expectations across the two stages.
source_text: This SS sets expectations for both the preparations for and execution of a solvent exit. Chapter 2 sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should prepare for an orderly solvent exit as part of its BAU activities. A firm should produce a ‘solvent exit analysis’ to meet the expectations in this Chapter. Chapter 3 sets out the PRA’s expectations for a firm to produce a ‘solvent exit execution plan’ when solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect for a firm. It also sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should manage and monitor the execution of a solvent exit.
target_text: This Chapter sets out the PRA’s expectations for how a firm should prepare for an orderly solvent exit 17 as part of its BAU activities. These expectations apply regardless of how unlikely or distant a prospect solvent exit may seem to the firm. If and when the execution of a solvent exit becomes a reasonable prospect, the firm should produce a ‘solvent exit execution plan’ as described in Chapter 3 .

question: If the participating Solvency II undertaking must calculate best estimates net of intra-group transactions (including making the required adjustments for intra-group reinsurance contracts), what data and documentation is it allowed to narrow its records to for this work?
gold_answer: The participating Solvency II undertaking must ensure that the best estimates of the participating Solvency II undertaking and of each related undertaking that is a Solvency II undertaking, third country insurance undertaking and third country reinsurance undertaking are net of any intra-group transactions, and it must make the required adjustments in relation to intra-group reinsurance contracts [#TGT:d7ed04a82cc5b9cd]. question: How should TWD firms use the PRA’s templates and instructions under this SS, and what does Template A show about the level of detail needed to analyse exit costs and liquidity flows using balance-sheet segmentation by method and price of exit?
gold_answer: TWD firms should use the PRA’s templates and accompanying instructions as the practical guide for what the PRA would expect them to be able to produce under the SS, including the overall breadth of data coverage and the granularity of the information they can generate [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c]. Template A (in Appendix 1) then illustrates what that expectation looks like for a specific analytical need: it provides a guide to the breadth and granularity of data that firms should be able to provide to demonstrate they can analyse exit costs and liquidity flows. The template’s focus makes clear that the firm’s data should support segmentation of the balance sheet by method and price of exit, so the firm can show how different exit methods and exit pricing affect both costs and liquidity movements [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8]. Taken together, the PRA’s templates/instructions set the general expectation for producible data under the SS, while Template A provides a concrete example of the kind of detailed, structured output a firm should be able to produce to evidence capability in exit-cost and liquidity-flow analysis using the specified balance-sheet segmentation dimensions [#TGT:13cf146179026c2c] [#SRC:87a878c6bb1a14e8].

question: When a derivative transaction has multiple material risk drivers and one of the relevant risk drivers is a climatic conditions variable, how shall institutions determine whether the transaction must be mapped to the commodity risk category and whether it must also be mapped to additional risk categories?
gold_answer: Institutions must apply a combined mapping approach that reflects both the climatic-conditions trigger and the multi-driver mapping requirement. First, if the primary risk driver of the transaction is a climatic conditions variable—or, for transactions where the mapping is performed by identifying the most material risk driver within a given risk category, the most material risk driver in that risk category is a climatic conditions variable—institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e]. In parallel, where the derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver, institutions shall map it to more than one risk category, allocating the transaction once to each risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, using the most material risk driver within each such risk category as the basis for that mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If all material risk drivers fall within the same risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category based on the most material driver; however, if drivers span different categories, the commodity mapping required by the climatic-conditions variable must be complemented by mapping to each other implicated risk category as applicable [#SRC:d444b5b1871ca35e] [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad].
source_text: (b) where the primary risk driver of a transaction, or the most material risk driver in a given risk category for transactions referred to in paragraph 3 , is a climatic conditions variable, institutions shall map the transaction to the commodity risk category.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: If Institutions have to publish the information covered by Titles II and III, what do they need to do so that the written explanation and any extra supporting information around the numbers is clear enough for users to understand the numbers, and where should that explanation appear in relation to the templates?
gold_answer: Institutions must publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in line with the applicable disclosure provisions, while recognising that this duty is subject to the stated exceptions. [#TGT:8764079e3800c628] When those public disclosures include quantitative disclosures, any qualitative narrative and any other necessary supplementary information that accompanies the quantitative disclosures must be written so it is adequately clear and comprehensive. The purpose of this requirement is to enable users of information to understand the quantitative disclosures, so the narrative and supplementary information must directly support comprehension of the figures rather than merely restating them. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] Institutions must also place that qualitative narrative and supplementary information next to the templates that the narrative describes, so users can read the explanation alongside the relevant quantitative templates. [#SRC:352a11b8f7285ab2] In practice, this means the public disclosure package should combine the required published information with adjacent, user-focused narrative that is sufficiently complete to make the quantitative disclosures understandable, consistent with the overall public disclosure obligation. [#TGT:8764079e3800c628]
source_text: The qualitative narrative and any other necessary supplementary information accompanying quantitative disclosures in accordance with Article 431 of the CRR shall be adequately clear and comprehensive, enabling users of information to understand the quantitative disclosures and shall be placed next to the templates, which they describe.
target_text: Institutions shall publicly disclose the information referred to in Titles II and III in accordance with the provisions laid down in this Title, subject to the exceptions referred to in Article 432 .

question: Can an institution work out one exposure value for a whole netting set under a contractual netting agreement, and at the same time permanently mix the relevant methods? Does it matter if it is a single institution or within a group?
gold_answer: An institution is allowed to calculate a single exposure value at netting set level for all transactions covered by a contractual netting agreement, but only if it meets the conditions attached to that permission [#TGT:1600c3275d4f97ef]. Separately, the rules on permanently combining the relevant methods draw a line between group use and single-institution use: institutions may combine those methods on a permanent basis within a group, but a single institution must not combine them on a permanent basis [#SRC:05cc39f7a09a2d78]. Putting these together, the netting-set exposure value permission does not remove the prohibition on permanent method-combination for a single institution. So, an institution may be able to compute one exposure value for the netting set if the contractual netting agreement conditions are met [#TGT:1600c3275d4f97ef], but if it is acting as a single institution it still cannot permanently mix the relevant methods; that permanent mixing is only allowed when done within a group [#SRC:05cc39f7a09a2d78].

question: When preparing a group recovery plan, how must firms that are parent entities of an international group demonstrate coverage of entities in other jurisdictions, and how must they document and explain dependencies between recovery options, including where options are mutually exclusive, in light of dependencies between group entities?
gold_answer: Firms that are parent entities of an international group must be able to show, within their group recovery plan, how they have covered the different entities located in other jurisdictions, rather than treating the plan as applying only to the parent or a single location [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. In doing so, the PRA expects firms to understand and reflect the dependencies between group entities, including both financial and non-financial dependencies, because these linkages affect how recovery actions can be executed across the group [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41]. Consistently, firms must detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive, so that the plan makes clear which actions can be pursued together and which cannot be combined [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6]. Taken together, this means the group recovery plan should connect entity coverage across jurisdictions with a clear mapping of option-to-option and entity-to-entity dependencies, enabling the PRA to assess whether proposed recovery actions are coherent across the international group and whether any constraints or incompatibilities have been explicitly identified [#SRC:21e8b786b13431f6] [#TGT:87b9b2ff210e1f41].
source_text: The PRA expects firms to detail and explain the dependencies between recovery options and clearly identify where recovery options are mutually exclusive (the interaction between recovery options at group and subsidiary levels is covered under ‘ (xi) Interaction between group and subsidiary plans ’ below).
target_text: The PRA expects firms that are parent entities of an international group to demonstrate how they have covered different entities in other jurisdictions in their group recovery plan. It is important for firms to understand dependencies, both financial and non-financial, between group entities.

question: For a PRA-regulated firm, how should the term “material outsourcing” be interpreted when the firm is entering into, or significantly changing, an outsourcing arrangement, and what notification timing is expected where the arrangement is within scope of OCIR or is expected to become material later?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm must notify the PRA when it is entering into, or significantly changing, a material outsourcing arrangement, and the PRA expects the notification to be made before the firm enters into the outsourcing arrangement [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]. In applying that obligation, “material outsourcing” should be interpreted by reference to whether the outsourced services fall within scope of OCIR, because where a firm outsources services to which OCIR applies, the arrangement will generally constitute material outsourcing [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. Even where OCIR does not apply, an outsourcing or non-outsourcing third party arrangement may still be material outsourcing if it could affect the PRA’s objectives outside an OCIR context, including where it involves personal or sensitive data or carries high reputational risk [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. The PRA also expects firms to submit notifications before an outsourcing arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become material, and it will consider the timeliness of notifications when assessing compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71].
source_text: Notifications 2.3(1)(e) requires all PRA-regulated firms, including credit unions and NDFs, to notify the PRA when ‘entering, or significantly changing a material outsourcing arrangement’. The PRA expects these notifications to be made before entering into the outsourcing arrangement. The PRA also expects firms to submit these notifications before an outsourcing arrangement that was not initially deemed material is expected or planned to become so (see paragraph 5.5 ). The PRA will consider the timeliness of these notifications when assessing firms’ compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 .
target_text: If a firm outsources services to which OCIR applies, this arrangement will generally constitute ‘material outsourcing’. However, outsourcing and non-outsourcing third party arrangements that are not within scope of OCIR might still be ‘material outsourcing’ if they could affect the PRA’s objectives outside of an OCIR context. Examples may include outsourcing arrangements involving personal or sensitive data or carrying high reputational risk.

question: How must an insurer align the establishment of its risk monitoring metrics with the obligation to maintain and monitor a liquidity buffer so that liabilities can be met as they fall due under both benign and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer must design and use its risk monitoring metrics in a way that directly supports how it determines, maintains, and evidences any liquidity buffer(s) it holds, because those metrics are part of the framework used to size and track liquid resources against expected outflows [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352]. In parallel, the insurer is required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of its investment portfolio and to consider whether its assets are appropriate to meet obligations as they fall due, which includes considering total liquidity needs and the level and monitoring of liquid assets [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. Practically, this means the insurer’s metrics should be capable of monitoring liquid assets and informing decisions about an appropriate liquidity buffer, including under stressed conditions, so the insurer can demonstrate it maintains an adequate stock of liquid assets sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due [#TGT:69f861caa7c533e0]. The linkage is that the metrics are not standalone reporting; they are used to support the establishment and ongoing adequacy of the liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer [#SRC:9c279e6bff2a8352].
source_text: used to support the establishment of the insurer’s risk monitoring metrics and any liquidity buffer(s) held by the insurer (set out in more detail in Chapter 5 );
target_text: Under Investments 2.1 , a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents are required to invest in assets that ensure the liquidity of their investment portfolio and, under Conditions Governing Business 3.1A(4)(b) , to consider the appropriateness of their assets in order to meet obligations as they fall due. Under paragraphs 1.63(b) and (c) of EIOPA Guideline 26 an insurer should consider its total liquidity needs, including an appropriate liquidity buffer and consider the level and monitoring of liquid assets, as well as potential haircuts that could be imposed on their sale. A non-Directive insurer, under Insurance Company – Overall Resources and Valuation 2.3 or Friendly Society – Financial Prudence 4.1 must maintain adequate liquidity to ensure there is no significant risk that its liabilities cannot be met as they fall due. An insurer must therefore maintain an adequate stock of liquid assets, hereafter called a ‘liquidity buffer’, sufficient to meet liabilities as they fall due, and is expected to do so under both benign and stressed conditions.

question: When a group includes more than one firm using an internal model, what must Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies do each year to meet the PRA’s analysis-of-change reporting requirement, and how does the PRA’s AoC.01 template fit into the required submission process?
gold_answer: Where reporting is being made on a group that includes more than one firm using an internal model, Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies must submit to the PRA an annual analysis-of-change return using template AoC.01, and that submission must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, prepared in line with the relevant instructions for the template [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556]. The PRA supports this obligation by providing an analysis of change template named AoC.01 for firms to complete, designed to capture key information regarding movement in the SCR, and the completed template is then submitted to the PRA as part of the reporting process described in the PRA Rulebook context referenced in the procedure [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]. In practice, this means the firm (or, where applicable, the UK holding company) should use the PRA-provided AoC.01 format to structure the required analysis-of-change content, ensure the template is completed with the key SCR movement information, and submit it annually to the PRA in the manner contemplated by the reporting framework and the template’s instructions [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291].
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies reporting information on a group which includes more than one firm using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: If a firm triggers an SPF for restructuring by engaging, or preparing to engage, in the restructuring activity, does it have to include third‑party fees and disbursements that are billed to the PRA for help with the PRA’s related regulatory work?
gold_answer: Yes. Once an SPF for restructuring becomes payable because a firm engages, or prepares to engage, in activity that involves it undertaking or making arrangements with a view to the specified outcomes, the payable amount must be calculated in a way that also captures certain external costs incurred by the PRA. In other words, the trigger for payment is the firm’s engagement (or preparation to engage) in the restructuring activity [#TGT:28f11ba870345a3b], and the calculation step requires including third‑party invoiced fees and disbursements to the PRA that relate to supporting the PRA’s performance of that regulatory work [#SRC:f9e22b9441fa0c58].

question: When the FSCS pays compensation, does it have to pay interest that has built up on eligible deposits but was not yet added to the account by the compensation date, and does paying that interest change the £120,000 maximum compensation sum for a depositor’s total eligible deposits?
gold_answer: Yes. The FSCS must reimburse interest owed on eligible deposits where the interest had accrued but had not been credited at the compensation date, except where the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f]. However, paying that interest does not increase the depositor’s compensation beyond the maximum compensation sum payable for the depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits. The definition sets that maximum at £120,000 for each depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits, while also noting that additional compensation may be payable in certain cases [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]. The interest reimbursement is therefore required, but it is capped: the FSCS must ensure that the payment of accrued-but-uncredited interest does not cause the depositor’s compensation to exceed the maximum compensation sum [#SRC:04c5ad45b6092e9f], as that maximum is defined for the depositor’s aggregate eligible deposits [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e]. If a depositor is in a category where additional compensation may be payable under the definition’s carve-out, that may affect the overall amount, but the general rule remains that interest reimbursement cannot be used to breach the stated maximum [#TGT:336f75f8cdcde56e].
source_text: Except where the compensation sum arises from a temporary high balance , the FSCS shall reimburse interest owed on eligible deposits which had accrued, but has not been credited, at the compensation date . The limit provided for in 4.2 shall not be exceeded by the payment of any such interest.
target_text: The maximum compensation sum payable for the aggregate eligible deposits of each depositor is £120,000, save that additional compensation may be payable in cases to which 4.3 or 4.4 apply.

question: For purposes of calculating RoA as a two-year average ratio, how must the “net income” input be identified and sourced, and how does that definition interact with the requirement to use total assets as the denominator?
gold_answer: RoA is defined as a metric computed by taking net income divided by total assets and then averaging that ratio over a two-year period, so the calculation requires a consistent identification of both the numerator and denominator across the relevant years [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505]. The “net income” component used as the numerator is not left to general interpretation; it is specifically tied to a FINREP data point, meaning net income must be taken from row 355, column 01 of template F02.00 (FINREP) [#TGT:faed71864e571bf4]. Read together, this means the RoA numerator must be sourced from that precise FINREP location for each year included in the two-year averaging window, while the denominator remains total assets as required by the RoA calculation construct [#SRC:005b0d8588b51505]. Accordingly, compliance hinges on (i) using the FINREP-defined net income figure as the numerator and (ii) applying it in the ratio to total assets, with the resulting annual ratios then averaged over two years, ensuring the same definitional basis for net income throughout [#TGT:faed71864e571bf4].
source_text: RoA will be calculated as the ratio of net income 8 to total assets 9 , and averaged over two years.
target_text: 8. Defined as row 355, column 01 of F02.00 (FINREP).

question: For a relevant currency, how should the ultimate forward rate be defined in terms of whether it incorporates any compensation for long-term investment risk, and what procedural constraints govern when the PRA may adjust that rate to preserve stability?
gold_answer: The ultimate forward rate should be understood as a long-term rate that is not uplifted by any additional component intended to compensate for the extra risk of holding long-term investments; in other words, it is defined without a term premium for that purpose [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d]. Procedurally, for each relevant currency the PRA sets the ultimate forward rate by taking account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, but only where those expectations can be determined reliably for that currency [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18]. Consistent with its stated objective to maintain stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency, the PRA will only make changes to the rate where there are changes in long-term expectations, rather than making adjustments for other factors such as adding a risk-related premium [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18]. In applying this approach, the PRA uses the same methodology as specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024, aligning the calculation process with that methodology while preserving the definition that excludes a term premium [#SRC:07f28fc667f26c18] [#TGT:87cfaaafc6a4804d].
source_text: For each relevant currency the ultimate forward rate takes account of expectations of the long-term real interest rate and expected inflation, provided those expectations can be determined for that currency in a reliable manner. The PRA will maintain stability in the ultimate forward rate for each relevant currency and will only make changes where there are changes in long-term expectations. The PRA uses the same methodology as that specified by EIOPA in its Report on the Calculation of the UFR for 2024. 4
target_text: The ultimate forward rate does not include a term premium to reflect the additional risk of holding long-term investments.

question: If a firm’s requirement tells it to calculate capital adequacy using either Part 1 or Part 2 of Annex 2, which set of definitions must it use for conglomerate capital resources and the conglomerate capital resources requirement, and how does that connect to the table entry that names the Part 1 method under the Financial Groups Directive (Accounting Consolidation Method)?
gold_answer: When a firm is subject to a requirement that prescribes the capital adequacy calculation by reference to either Part 1 or Part 2 of Annex 2, the firm must use the definitions of “conglomerate capital resources” and “conglomerate capital resources requirement” from the same Part that the requirement specifies [#SRC:089b26c5ed6f0d12]. In other words, the firm does not mix and match definitions across Parts; it follows the Part named in the requirement. The target text helps identify what “Part 1” refers to in a related cross-reference by listing a table entry for “PART 1: Method of Annex I of the Financial Groups Directive (Accounting Consolidation Method)” [#TGT:78cd1c923c80862d]. So, if the firm’s requirement points to Part 1, the firm should (i) take the relevant definitions from Part 1 as directed by the source rule, and (ii) understand that the Part 1 method being referenced in the table is the accounting consolidation method under the Financial Groups Directive. If the requirement instead points to Part 2, the firm would take the definitions from Part 2.
source_text: If a firm is subject to a requirement that prescribes the capital adequacy calculation by reference to one or other of Parts 1 and 2 of Annex 2 , the definitions of conglomerate capital resources and conglomerate capital resources requirement that apply for the purposes of 3.3 are the definitions from whichever of Part 1 or Part 2 of Annex 2 is specified in the requirement .

question: If a derivative transaction has more than one material risk driver and must be mapped to more than one risk category, how does an institution decide whether it is long or short in the most material risk driver for each risk category, using the rule about when the transaction’s market value increases?
gold_answer: An institution must map a derivative transaction that has more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category, unless all of the transaction’s material risk drivers are in the same risk category, in which case it maps the transaction only once to that single category using the most material risk driver [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the institution maps the transaction once to each relevant risk category, and for each category it uses the most material risk driver within that category as the basis for mapping [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. After that, the institution determines whether its position in the primary risk driver or most material risk driver (for the given risk category) is long or short by checking how the transaction’s market value reacts when that risk driver’s value increases: market value increasing implies a long position, while market value decreasing implies a short position [#SRC:c6e60ca38b4dc301]. This means the long/short assessment is tied to the specific most material risk driver used for each mapped risk category.
source_text: For the purposes of this Section, a long position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction increases when the value of that risk driver increases and a short position in the primary risk driver or in the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) means that the market value of the transaction decreases when the value of that risk driver increases.
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: When must institutions begin making the additional annual disclosures tied to a 5% non-performing loans and advances ratio, and what threshold-testing conditions govern the start of disclosure and the first reference date templates?
gold_answer: Institutions must commence disclosure once the 5% threshold condition is met under the commencement test in the SOURCE, and, where applicable, they must also satisfy the TARGET’s requirement for large institutions to provide specified additional annual disclosures when their ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances to total gross carrying amount of loans and advances is equal to or higher than 5%. Under the SOURCE, institutions start disclosure where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the disclosure reference date, and for the first disclosure reference date they must disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that reference date [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]. In parallel, the TARGET imposes an annual disclosure obligation on large institutions meeting the 5% ratio test, requiring the disclosures required in specified points of Article 442 of the CRR to be made also in accordance with the listed templates and related annex instructions [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37]. Read together, commencement timing and first-reference-date template inclusion follow the SOURCE’s threshold mechanics, while the content and annual cadence for large institutions meeting the ratio test follow the TARGET.
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: When deposits become unavailable deposits, what must a firm deliver to the FSCS, in what format, and within what deadline, taking into account both the requirement to provide single customer view and exclusions view information and the expectation that the firm can produce the relevant SCV and exclusions view files on demand?
gold_answer: When the relevant deposits become unavailable deposits, a firm must provide the FSCS with the required single customer view information and the related exclusions view information within 24 hours. Under the TARGET obligation, this is framed as providing to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within that 24-hour window once the deposits are unavailable deposits [#TGT:6fe4cdb3f52e1619]. The SOURCE complements this by specifying the deliverable form as an SCV file and an exclusions view file, and by reinforcing the same 24-hour timing expectation for providing those files to the FSCS (and also to the PRA) when a deposit becomes an unavailable deposit, as well as when the PRA or the FSCS requests them [#SRC:f27237aae9113a6c]. Read together, the firm’s compliance outcome is that it must be operationally ready to generate and submit the SCV file and exclusions view file so that the FSCS receives the complete set of single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the triggering event, and the firm should maintain readiness to meet the same file-submission requirement upon request within the applicable time period.
source_text: Depositor Protection 12.1 and 12.2 set out that a firm must provide an SCV file and an exclusions view file to the PRA or the FSCS within 24 hours of a deposit becoming an unavailable deposit or request by the PRA or the FSCS. The PRA considers that the beginning of the 24-hour period can be taken as the end of the business day on which the request was made. The PRA or the FSCS may request the submission of an SCV file and exclusions view file at any time, including as part of the business as usual review programme. As such, firms should be ready and able to submit SCV and exclusions view files to the PRA and FSCS upon request, and within the time period set out in the depositor protection rules.
target_text: A firm must provide to the FSCS all single customer views and exclusions views within 24 hours of the relevant deposits becoming unavailable deposits .

question: What is the Transfer Summary, and when can a society send it to members instead of the Transfer Statement, given that the PRA approves the Transfer Statement that must be sent to members?
gold_answer: The Transfer Summary is defined as the summary of the Transfer Statement that may be sent instead of the Transfer Statement, and it is linked to the notice for the meeting where the Transfer Resolutions will be considered. Specifically, it may (in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act) be sent in or with the notice of that meeting to every member who is entitled to receive the notice [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f]. The source context explains that the PRA’s role includes approving the Transfer Statement, which must be sent to the members, and that the chapter also covers the PRA’s role in the confirmation procedure and its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0]. Putting these together, the society’s ability to send the Transfer Summary is a permitted alternative to sending the full Transfer Statement in the specific meeting-notice setting, while the PRA’s approval role remains tied to the Transfer Statement that is otherwise required to be sent to members during the transfer process [#SRC:bc1b187c93910ab0] and the defined scope of the Transfer Summary [#TGT:a14772d46835cf4f].
source_text: The chapter also describes the role of the PRA in approving the Transfer Statement which must be sent to the members and in the confirmation procedure, together with its ongoing prudential supervision during the transfer process. The Transfer Summary, 44 which a society may send to its members instead of the Transfer Statement, is also discussed.
target_text: 44. The summary of the Transfer Statement which may, in accordance with Schedule 17 to the 1986 Act, be sent, instead of the Transfer Statement, in or with the notice of the meeting at which the Transfer Resolutions are to be considered, to every member entitled to receive that notice.

question: If a firm uses the TMTP method and has a transfer event that changes the technical provisions covered by TMTP, what does it have to do to update its TMTP methodology, and when should the transferred TMTP be calculated relative to the effective date?
gold_answer: When a firm uses the TMTP method and a ‘transfer event’ causes a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates, the firm is required to make an update to its TMTP methodology [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. For the part of the TMTP that is being transferred, the firm should calculate the ‘transferred TMTP’ immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction, so the transferred amount is set based on the position just before the transfer becomes effective [#TGT:a7aad619cba8176e]. The firm can only make this update if the business that has been transferred or ceded was already subject to TMTP before the transfer, which limits the update to TMTP-covered business rather than newly in-scope business [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. The PRA also expects the update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction, aligning the update process with the transfer timing while still requiring the transferred TMTP calculation to be done immediately before that effective date [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b; #TGT:a7aad619cba8176e].
source_text: Firms that use the TMTP method are required by Transitional Measures on Technical Provisions 6 to make an update to their TMTP methodology following a ‘transfer event’ which has resulted in a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates. They are also permitted to make revisions to the business designated to the dynamic portion in order to designate acquired business that is MA-eligible in respect of that firm.. Transfer events are: 1) transfer of business either under Part VII of Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) or the Friendly Societies Act 1992; 2) the transfer of risk under a 100% reinsurance contract; 3) an amendment to an existing 100% reinsurance contract if there has been a change to the volume of risk to which the reinsurer is exposed; and 4) cancellation, commutation, termination or expiration of an 100% reinsurance contract. Such an update would only be permitted if the business that has been transferred or ceded was subject to TMTP prior to the transfer. The PRA expects this update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction. 5
target_text: 5. The ‘transferred TMTP’ should be as calculated immediately prior to the effective date of the transfer or transaction.

question: What must a firm include in its internal credit assessment so that the fundamental spread reflects all the risks the senior notes face, including how different qualitative and quantitative risks can combine or interact?
gold_answer: A firm must make sure its internal credit assessment covers all risks to which the senior notes are exposed, including combinations of risks, and that this assessment feeds through to the assigned CQS and the derivation of the basic FS, including any adjustments made to reflect differences in credit quality by rating notch [#SRC:baebcddb0c257a4e]. At the same time, because the FS is meant to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption the asset is held until maturity (except where sale is necessary for rebalancing the MA portfolio to restore the overall matching position after material cash-flow changes), the firm must treat retained risks as including both qualitative and quantitative risks and must consider how these risks may interact [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2]. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data, and quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses; the list is not exhaustive, so the firm should not limit its assessment to only the examples provided [#TGT:5ef1d5a9b4e454c2].
source_text: As mentioned in paragraphs 2.1 and 2.3 above, firms should consider both qualitative and quantitative sources of risk in their credit risk assessments. The PRA expects that all of the risks to which the senior notes are exposed (including combinations of risks) will be considered in the internal credit assessment, the assigned CQS and therefore the derivation of the basic FS (including any adjustments made to it in order to take account of differences in credit quality by rating notch).
target_text: The overarching aim of the FS is to determine how much of the spread on an eligible asset should be taken to reflect the risks retained by the firm on the assumption that the asset is held until maturity (other than where it proves necessary to sell it, as part of rebalancing the MA portfolio, for the purpose of restoring the overall matching position where the asset and/or liability cash flows of the portfolio have materially changed). Retained risks include both qualitative and quantitative risks. Qualitative risks may include the strength of the terms and conditions in the loan agreement or a lack of default data. Quantitative risks may include economic or market stresses. Internal credit assessments must also consider how these risks may interact (as per Matching Adjustment 7.2(1) ). The examples of risks listed in this paragraph are not exhaustive.

question: For general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, how is the scope of the applicable requirement determined across the two regimes—specifically, which underlying provision is triggered in each, what percentage substitution must be applied, and what condition set must be satisfied for the substitution to operate?
gold_answer: Where the business is general insurance business consisting of health insurance based on actuarial principles, each regime brings a different underlying provision into scope and modifies it by substituting a different percentage, but only once the relevant conditions are met. Under the SOURCE, the applicable framework is the one that would otherwise apply under the referenced provision, but it is applied on a modified basis: the percentage used is substituted to 8.66% in place of 26%, and this modified application is contingent on satisfying the conditions identified as those in 7.5 (1) to (5) [#SRC:19c9e8d0b9a70534]. Under the TARGET, the same type of business instead triggers application of 7.4, again with a substitution mechanism: 6% is substituted for 18%, and this operates only if the “following conditions” are satisfied as specified in that text [#TGT:c34927b3fbe2f827]. Read together, the scope boundary is the same business type, but the operative provision, the substituted percentage, and the way the condition set is referenced differ between the two passages.

question: If a derivative transaction seems to have more than one important risk driver, what must institutions do to map it to risk categories, and how does that fit with the rule that mapping is based on the primary risk driver as the only material risk driver?
gold_answer: Institutions have to align the mapping approach across both texts. The TARGET requires institutions to do the mapping based on the primary risk driver of the derivative transaction, and it also states that the primary risk driver is the only material risk driver of that transaction [#TGT:7c541aa6ba03b9a1]. The SOURCE addresses the situation where a transaction has more than one material risk driver and sets the mapping outcome: institutions must map the transaction to more than one risk category, except where all material risk drivers are in the same risk category, in which case the transaction is mapped only once to that category using the most material risk driver; where the material risk drivers fall into different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each such category, using the most material risk driver within each category [#SRC:28d975e9bccdd9ad]. Taken together, institutions must ensure their mapping is driven by the relevant risk driver basis (primary/most material) while applying the SOURCE’s rules on whether mapping occurs once or across multiple risk categories.
source_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.
target_text: Institutions shall conduct the mapping referred to in paragraph 1 on the basis of the primary risk driver of a derivative transaction. The primary risk driver shall be the only material risk driver of a derivative transaction.

question: When assessing whether a local entity’s risk can be treated as already addressed, how should the analysis distinguish between mitigation achieved through the risk based capital framework or other means and mitigation achieved at the group level through group risk management processes or internal control mechanisms?
gold_answer: In evaluating whether a local entity’s risk can be treated as already addressed, the analysis should explicitly map the mitigation to one of two pathways and document which applies. First, determine whether the relevant risks are already mitigated through the risk based capital framework or by other means, as this indicates the risk is addressed within the capital-based approach or an alternative mitigation method recognized in the same context [#SRC:d59b0f174c2241e4]. Second, assess whether the risk of the local entity is mitigated at the group level through risk management processes or internal control mechanisms established at the group level, which frames mitigation as arising from group-level governance and controls rather than solely from capital treatment [#TGT:7a8270fc93e6d439]. Where both appear to apply, the assessment should explain how the group-level processes or controls interact with, complement, or substitute for the capital framework or other means, so that the conclusion that the risk is “already mitigated” is traceable to the specific mechanism relied upon and avoids double-counting the same mitigation effect.

target_text: 21. For example, the risk of a local entity might be mitigated at the group level through risk management processes or internal control mechanisms established at the group level.

question: In scenario testing of a recovery plan, how should the selection of a subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses be used to evidence that the plan remains suitable across different types of stress and that key plan elements interact effectively?
gold_answer: Scenario testing should be used to connect two complementary objectives: (1) selecting the subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses, and (2) demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable across a range of different types of stress while showing how plan elements interact under those stresses. Practically, the scenario design should require the recovery plan to identify, for each specific stress, which options are realistically expected to be selected (i.e., a subset rather than an exhaustive list), and then use those selections as the basis for testing the plan’s operation in that stress. The testing should explicitly examine how the chosen options work alongside other elements of the plan—such as indicators and governance—to show whether the plan functions coherently when pressures vary in type and severity. This approach ensures the scenario exercise is not merely theoretical, but instead focuses on likely decision pathways and their operational implications, while still supporting the broader demonstration that the recovery plan can be used in multiple stress conditions and that its components interact as intended [#SRC:db5203b384a28349] [#TGT:3cc3932a984e4450].
source_text: the selection of the subset of options that would likely be chosen to respond to specific stresses (covered under ‘ (iv) Scenario testing ’ below).
target_text: Scenario testing is important for demonstrating that the recovery plan is suitable for use in a range of different types of stress, and testing how different elements of the plan (such as indicators, governance and options) would interact in these stresses.

question: If a merger includes a bonus for members, what does the Statement have to say about it, and when does the bonus approval have to be put into the Merger Resolutions for just one society versus every participating society?
gold_answer: Where a merger proposal involves paying a bonus to members as consideration for the merger, the Statement must spell out that bonus (if any) so the proposal clearly identifies what is to be paid [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8]. In addition, members must approve bonus payments through the Merger Resolutions, and the rules on which societies’ resolutions must contain that approval depend on the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), measured without any adjustment for prospective corporation tax recovery [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the approval only needs to be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, then the approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]. Together, this means the Statement’s required bonus specification aligns with, and supports, the member-approval mechanics that must be embedded in the Merger Resolutions [#SRC:3c15426a910415a8] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8].
source_text: Paragraph 1(4)(d) of Schedule 16 to the 1986 Act requires the Statement to specify the bonus, if any, to be paid to members in consideration of the merger. The PRA’s views on what may, or may not, be regarded as bonus are given in paragraphs 3.41 to 3.42 , and the statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus).
