question: How must a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents implement and maintain a risk management system so that it both supports approved risk tolerance limits (including liquidity risk appetite and prudent limits) and also operates as an effective, continuous system for identifying, measuring, monitoring, managing and reporting risks at individual and aggregated levels, including interdependencies?
gold_answer: A UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents must implement and maintain a risk management system that is not only maintained as an ongoing control framework, but is also structured to embed approved risk tolerance limits that implement the insurer’s risk strategy and facilitate control mechanisms [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510]. In parallel, the system must be effective in design and operation, comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures that enable the firm to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report risks on a continuous basis, both at individual and aggregated levels, and to address the interdependencies among those risks [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Consistent with the source expectations for liquidity risk, senior management should use this system to maintain a clearly defined liquidity risk appetite statement, identify material sources of liquidity risk, and set prudent risk limits for those sources, so that liquidity risk is captured within the broader continuous risk identification and reporting cycle [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510]. Together, these requirements mean the risk management system must translate risk strategy into measurable limits and governance while also delivering continuous, enterprise-wide risk measurement and reporting capability [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].
source_text: Conditions Governing Business 3.1(1A)(c) requires UK Solvency II firms, the Society and managing agents to implement and maintain a risk management system that includes approved risk tolerance limits that implement an insurer’s risk strategy and facilitate control mechanisms. Consistent with this obligation, the PRA expects a UK Solvency II firm, the Society and managing agents to establish and maintain a clearly defined liquidity risk appetite statement and for senior management to identify material sources of liquidity risk for which prudent risk limits should be set. For non-Directive firms, Non-Solvency II Firms – Governance 7.3(2) requires an insurer to document its policies in relation to liquidity risk, including its appetite or tolerance for this risk.
target_text: (1) A firm must establish, implement, and maintain an effective risk-management system comprising strategies, processes and reporting procedures necessary to identify, measure, monitor, manage and report on a continuous basis the risks, at an individual and at an aggregated level, to which it is or could be exposed, and their interdependencies.

question: How must a firm ensure that its governance arrangements are not only established for prudent management of its own business, but also applied consistently across all undertakings within the scope of group supervision so that governance and reporting can be controlled at group level?
gold_answer: A firm must first ensure it has an effective system of governance in place that supports sound and prudent management of its business [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. In addition, where there are undertakings included in the scope of group supervision, the firm must ensure that the effective system of governance and the associated reporting procedures are implemented consistently across all those undertakings, rather than applied unevenly or only within the firm itself [#SRC:81456a787f326c75]. This consistent implementation is required so that the governance and reporting procedures can be controlled at the level of the group, meaning the arrangements should be capable of being overseen and managed on a group-wide basis, not merely at individual-entity level [#SRC:81456a787f326c75]. Taken together, the obligations require both (i) establishment of an effective governance system for the firm’s prudent management and (ii) consistent, group-wide implementation of governance and reporting procedures across the supervised group to enable effective group-level control [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6] [#SRC:81456a787f326c75].
source_text: (2) Without prejudice to (1), the effective system of governance and reporting procedures must be implemented consistently in all the undertakings included in the scope of group supervision under 2.2(1) and 2.2(2) so that the effective system of governance and reporting procedures can be controlled at the level of the group .
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place an effective system of governance which provides for sound and prudent management of its business.

question: When a firm wants to use the standard approach for the FS addition for event risks on a pooled asset exposure (because the underlying assets are mainly economic risk and the exposure is predictable), what does the PRA mean by event-driven cash flow variability risk, and what percentile-style benchmark does the PRA link to that risk when better data allows more advanced modelling?
gold_answer: If a pooled asset exposure’s underlying assets are exposed to economic risks, and the firm has enough evidence that the exposure is predictable, the firm may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855]. In doing so, the firm should define the relevant event risk in the way the PRA characterises it: event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be appropriately represented using fatter-tailed distributions, meaning the firm should not assume that event impacts on cash flows are narrowly distributed around the average [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA links this definition to a practical benchmark for provision: a provision equal to one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is described as broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution, and this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks [#TGT:24cba8bb8769696c]. This benchmark can therefore be used to support and explain the firm’s proposal under the standard approach permission [#SRC:957d2122eefbf855].
source_text: The PRA has set out expectations in paragraphs 5.23 to 5.25 below for standard approaches for economic and event risk exposures. For assets with both economic and event risk exposures, firms should follow the approach for the dominant risks. For pooled asset exposures where the underlying assets are exposed to economic risks but where there is sufficient evidence of predictability, firms may propose to apply the standard approach to the FS addition for event risks.
target_text: The PRA considers that event-driven cash flow variability risks are more likely to be best represented by fatter-tailed distributions. Where more complete credible data becomes available to support more sophisticated modelling, the PRA considers that a provision of one quarter of the difference in MA benefit from median to worst cash flows is broadly equivalent to targeting the 85th percentile of a fatter-tailed distribution and that this would likely demonstrate adequate provision for the additional retained cash flow variability risks.

question: When a firm permits deviations from the booking model policy, what must the firm do to ensure those deviations remain tightly controlled through a documented, explicitly approved exception process, and how must the firm’s assurance functions assess the relevant procedures to provide independent oversight?
gold_answer: The firm must treat any deviation from the booking model policy as an exception that is both rare and handled only through an explicitly approved exception process that is documented within the same booking model policy, with appropriate involvement of the firm in that process [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a]. In parallel, the firm must ensure independent oversight of the procedures that govern how such matters are handled by subjecting those procedures to assessment by assurance functions, specifically including compliance, operational risk and internal audit [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2]. Read together, this means the firm should not allow ad hoc departures from the policy: deviations must be channelled through the documented approval pathway, and the underlying procedures supporting that pathway should be independently assessed by the named assurance functions. This combination supports both front-line control (rare, explicitly approved, policy-documented exceptions with firm involvement) and second/third-line challenge (assurance assessment of the procedures) to help ensure deviations are justified, consistently processed, and appropriately governed across the firm [#TGT:00ebc8f04ba1902a] [#SRC:05c733f03ee2bae2].
source_text: Independent review: The procedures set out in 4.25H - 4.25U are expected to be subject to assessment by assurance functions such as compliance, operational risk and internal audit.
target_text: Exceptions: Any deviations from the booking model policy should occur rarely and only by way of an explicitly approved exception process documented in the same policy with appropriate involvement of the firm.

question: When applying Table A’s default approach to interpreting EU-based references, what procedural steps should be followed if a provision uses the Euro only as an illustrative currency example but applies the same treatment to other currencies (e.g., US dollars), and does this require any change to the interpretation?
gold_answer: The procedure is to start by using Table A as the controlling framework for categorising the relevant EU-based reference and applying the default approach specified for how that reference should be interpreted [#SRC:dd9730c74dae4fce]. Then, when you encounter drafting that uses the Euro as an example of a currency, you should check whether the provision applies the same treatment to other currencies (for example, US dollars). If the treatment is the same, you should proceed on the basis that no adjustment is needed to the interpretive outcome you would otherwise reach under the Table A default approach; in other words, the example currency does not trigger a different reading or a separate interpretive step [#TGT:0f091b34fb7fe524]. Operationally, this means you document that the Euro reference is illustrative, confirm equivalence of treatment across currencies, and continue applying the Table A default interpretation without modification. This aligns the general default interpretive method for EU-based references with the specific instruction that currency examples do not, by themselves, require interpretive change when the underlying treatment is consistent.
source_text: Table A sets out the various different types of EU-based references, and a default approach to how these should be interpreted.
target_text: Where Euro is given as an example of a currency, and the same treatment is applied to other currencies (eg US dollars), no change in interpretation is required.

question: If a firm has been told by its supervisor that it qualifies for Simplified Obligations, what does it still need to do about recovery plan scenarios, and what parts of recovery planning are reduced for that firm?
gold_answer: Simplified Obligations apply only to firms that the PRA applies them to and that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria; for those firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template [#SRC:1714a0d1f587bfcb]. Even so, the PRA expects firms to follow the EBA ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’ alongside the expectations in the supervisory statement [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]. That means an eligible firm should still include at least two scenarios from the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9]. In line with the EBA guidelines, the firm should also include a scenario that combines system-wide and idiosyncratic events, and the PRA expects firms (including those eligible for Simplified Obligations) to include this combined scenario because it is the most challenging and requires considering trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing the recovery strategy [#TGT:9394388668fe0fa9].
source_text: The PRA applies Simplified Obligations for recovery planning (Simplified Obligations) to firms that have been notified by their supervisor that they meet the eligibility criteria. For these firms, the reduced recovery planning obligations apply in respect of scenarios and the information template (paragraphs 2.54 – 2.55 and 2.70 ). Additional information in relation to the approach that smaller and less complex firms should take in respect of certain aspects of recovery planning is included where relevant in this SS.
target_text: The EBA has published ‘Guidelines on the range of scenarios to be used in recovery plans’. The PRA expects firms to follow these guidelines alongside the expectations set out in this SS. Firms that are eligible for Simplified Obligations should include at least two of the scenarios set out in the EBA guidelines that are sufficiently severe to test the recovery plan and are most relevant to the firm’s business model. In accordance with the EBA guidelines, firms should include a scenario with a combination of system-wide and idiosyncratic events. The PRA therefore expects firms, including those eligible for Simplified Obligations, to include a combined system-wide and idiosyncratic event, as these scenarios are the most challenging, as firms need to consider potential trade-offs between capital and liquidity impacts from recovery options when developing a recovery strategy.

question: A firm must keep the statement of responsibilities record for each key function holder up to date. When the firm creates or updates that record, who must sign it?
gold_answer: The firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder, so the firm needs to maintain a current record for every key function holder [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba]. Alongside that ongoing maintenance duty, the record must be formally signed: the record itself and each updated version must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715]. This means that whenever the firm first prepares the record, it must obtain both signatures, and whenever the firm updates the record to keep it current, it must again ensure the updated version is signed by both the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm. The combined effect is that the firm is responsible not only for keeping the content current for each key function holder, but also for ensuring that every version that is current has the required sign-off from the individual key function holder and the firm’s representative [#TGT:1d05aec0b357c9ba] [#SRC:8e03ecfaf3ea1715].
source_text: The record in 5.4 , and each updated version, must be signed by the key function holder and an appropriate representative of the firm .
target_text: A firm must keep an up-to-date record of the statement of responsibilities of each key function holder .

question: For entitlement to vote on a shareholding members resolution, how is the qualifying shareholding date determined, and in what circumstances is a person prohibited from treating an overdrawn share account as satisfying a requirement to hold shares on that date or during the relevant period?
gold_answer: The qualifying shareholding date is defined by reference to the voting date: it is either the last day of the financial year immediately preceding the voting date, or—where the voting date falls after the conclusion of the society’s AGM commenced in that financial year—the first day of the period that begins 56 days before the meeting date [#TGT:8b090799d8ee6d60]. That definition sets the date (or period) against which any shareholding condition must be tested for voting entitlement on a shareholding members resolution. However, when assessing whether a person meets a requirement for holding shares on that qualifying date (or during any required period), the person is prohibited from relying on a share account that has an overdrawn balance; such an overdrawn share account cannot be used to satisfy a shareholding requirement on a given date or during a given period [#SRC:5292b5d19dc62407]. Accordingly, even if the qualifying shareholding date is correctly identified under the definition, the underlying shareholding must be genuine and not merely an overdrawn account position, because that would not meet the holding-shares requirement for the relevant date or period.
source_text: There is no requirement for continuity of shareholding between paragraphs 3.111(a) and (b) (In contrast, in the case of an ordinary or special resolution, membership at paragraph 3.111(a) may be satisfied by either borrowing or shareholding membership provided the shareholding member satisfies the other conditions of paragraph 3.111(b) to (d) in order to vote in his or her capacity as a shareholder). Note also that a person cannot meet a requirement for holding shares on a given date, or during a given period, by relying on his holding of a share account with an overdrawn balance; and a person cannot meet a requirement for being a member on a given date (for example, at paragraph 3.111(a) ) by relying on his holding of such a share account.

question: If a firm holds assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, what must it do to find all the cash flow timing/amount uncertainties and make sure the extra risks from cash flow variability are properly covered in the FS, and what does the PRA expect the firm to write down?
gold_answer: If a firm includes assets with HP cash flows in its MA portfolio, it must recognise that these assets are likely to add extra risk and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required to provision for those additional risks [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. The firm must also identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for those uncertainties, so that the FS outcome reflects the full set of relevant uncertainties rather than only a subset [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121]. Alongside this, the firm should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, using the guidance referenced in the source passage to support that assessment [#SRC:b728c6d47d520ce6]. The PRA expects the firm to document the details of the sources of uncertainty it has identified and to document how it has allowed for them, providing a clear record that the FS increases and other FS additions are grounded in the firm’s identified variability and uncertainty drivers [#TGT:a84f9442b495f121].
source_text: Firms should consider additional risks that arise from sources of cash flow variability, and ensure that these risks have been sufficiently captured by the required FS additions, based on guidance set out in paragraphs 5.17 to 5.29 of this chapter.
target_text: Assets with HP cash flows are likely to introduce additional risks into firms’ MA portfolios and therefore increases to the FS for these assets will be required (in accordance with Matching Adjustment 4.16 ) to provision for these additional risks. As required by Chapter 8 of the Matching Adjustment Part , firms must identify all sources of uncertainty in cash flow timing and/or amount and make an adequate allowance for these. The PRA expects firms to document details of these sources of uncertainty and how they have allowed for them.

question: If a TWD firm needs to update the TWD option within weeks, how should it decide what counts as a “material component,” and what must it set up so it can consistently refresh assumptions, modelling/methodology, and scenario factors when changes could affect decisions?
gold_answer: A TWD firm must be able to refresh the material components of the TWD option within weeks through a “full plan refresh,” which includes updating the assumptions and approximations that inform the TWD option, updating the modelling or methodology used for information provision and decision-making, and updating the factors that make up the TWD scenario [#SRC:76a8dbf9e47fc1dd]. To decide what is in scope for that refresh, material components are those where the impact of a change could influence decision-making, and TWD firms must define what they mean by “material component” and set thresholds for what level of change is treated as material [#TGT:8d564dede4742c2a]. In practice, the firm’s definitions and thresholds provide the consistent trigger points for identifying decision-relevant changes and ensuring they are captured in the full plan refresh within the required weeks-long timeframe, rather than being handled ad hoc or inconsistently across different assumptions, methods, or scenario drivers.
source_text: Refresh capabilities: these capabilities enable a firm to refresh the information supporting the development and execution of the TWD option in a timely manner. Firms should be able to refresh data on their balance sheet (including data on trading book positions at the individual contract, collateral and asset levels), their quantification of wind-down costs, and capital and liquidity projections, within a matter of days (the ‘data refresh’). Firms should be able to refresh the material components of the TWD option, including changes to assumptions and approximations that inform the TWD option, changes to the modelling or methodology firms use as part of their information provision and decision-making capabilities, and changes to the factors that make up the TWD scenario within weeks (the ‘full plan refresh’). 10
target_text: 10. Material components are those whereby the impact of a change could influence decision-making. TWD firms should define material component and change thresholds.

question: What does “sleeper collateral” mean for an insurer, and why is it relevant when counterparties or other market participants create liquidity stress by recalling it or triggering collateral posting issues?
gold_answer: For an insurer, “sleeper collateral” means the value of collateral the insurer is already contractually required to post to a counterparty, but has not actually posted yet because the counterparty has not called for it [#TGT:17e755beec91fb74]. It becomes relevant in liquidity-stress analysis because the source describes how actions of counterparties and other market participants can create liquidity stresses that adversely affect the insurer, including by recalling sleeper collateral, by situations where collateral required is not posted, or by opening valuation disputes [#SRC:4fbd64abc69cb404]. In practical terms, the definition clarifies that sleeper collateral is not “optional” collateral; it is an existing obligation that is simply untriggered until a call occurs. Under the stressed conditions described, a call or recall can rapidly turn that unposted obligation into a near-term liquidity need, potentially alongside market price impacts from other participants selling similar assets the insurer may rely on for liquidity.
source_text: actions of counterparties, and other market participants experiencing liquidity stresses that could adversely affect the insurer, for instance by selling similar assets to those that the insurer may rely on for liquidity and affecting market prices, recalling sleeper collateral, 17 not posting collateral required, or opening valuation disputes.
target_text: 17. Sleeper collateral refers to the value of collateral that an insurer is contractually obliged to post to a counterparty, but has not yet posted as it has not yet been called by the counterparty.

question: If firms have to make sure they can keep delivering their important business services within impact tolerances, what should they do in practice, and where does the March 2021 SS1/21 link point them to find the relevant document?
gold_answer: Firms must take action to ensure they are able to deliver their important business services within their impact tolerances, after the Operational Resilience Parts of the PRA Rulebook and SS1/21 have required and expected them to identify those important business services and set impact tolerances for them [#SRC:f9622b5d346bca89]. In practice, the passage explains that firms should test against severe but plausible operational disruption scenarios so they can identify vulnerabilities and take mitigating action; and if deficiencies are found, the PRA’s operational resilience policy requires boards and senior management to drive improvement, linking operational testing outcomes to governance-led remediation [#SRC:f9622b5d346bca89]. The TARGET adds the specific reference point needed to locate the SS1/21 source material: it identifies “March 2021” and provides the Bank of England URL for the SS1/21 publication, which firms can use to access the supervisory statement that underpins these expectations and align their actions accordingly [#TGT:1553145ecbcbd731].
source_text: The Operational Resilience Parts of the PRA Rulebook 2 and SS1/21 ‘Operational resilience: Impact tolerances for important business services’ 3 respectively require and expect firms to identify important business services and set impact tolerances for these services. Firms must take action to ensure they are able to deliver their important business services 4 within their impact tolerances. 5 Testing against severe but plausible operational disruption scenarios enables firms to identify vulnerabilities and take mitigating action. The PRA’s operational resilience policy requires boards and senior management to drive improvement where deficiencies are found.

question: When the scope condition is met such that specified requirements (including External Audit provisions) are to be applied with any necessary changes at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, what reporting must the relevant insurance group undertakings or any UK holding company make to the group supervisor regarding significant risk concentrations, and how often must that reporting occur?
gold_answer: If the scope trigger is met so that the specified requirements (including External Audit provisions) apply with any necessary changes at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, then the reporting obligation in the paired provision must be met at the group level as applicable [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. question: When designing and operating its risk-management system, what must the firm do to ensure it covers risks included (and not fully included) in the SCR calculation, and how must the firm’s calibration approach ensure that all quantifiable risks—at least those enumerated—are taken into account?
gold_answer: The firm must ensure its risk-management system is effective and well integrated into its organisational structure and decision-making processes, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, and it must cover both the risks to be included in the SCR calculation and the risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]. Alongside this system-level coverage obligation, the firm must ensure that the relevant calibration is set so that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]. Together, these requirements mean the firm cannot treat SCR risk coverage as limited to a narrow set of modeled items: the risk-management system must be broad enough to capture SCR-included risks and any residual or excluded risks, while the calibration requirement ensures that, for quantifiable exposures, the firm’s approach explicitly incorporates the minimum specified risk categories and does not leave out other quantifiable risks.

question: If you need the Bank’s indicative thresholds for setting preferred resolution strategies and MREL requirements, what documents or webpages should you use, and where on the Bank of England site is the right link?

question: When submitting an application to the PRA for confirmation of an amalgamation or a transfer of engagements, may the parties include additional narrative in the scrutineers report beyond the required enclosure, and if so, what extra matters does the PRA indicate it would find helpful to be covered where invalid votes appear significant?
gold_answer: In an application for confirmation submitted to the PRA, the parties must enclose the scrutineers report as part of the application package, alongside the other required supporting documents (including the certified minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved) [#SRC:05dcadd91554d83e]. In addition to that required enclosure, the PRA indicates it is permitted and would be helpful for the scrutineers report to go further than simply reporting the voting outcome by also addressing process quality: it should comment on any procedural difficulties encountered during the voting process and provide an analysis of why votes were found to be invalid, but specifically where the number of invalid votes appears to be significant [#TGT:2c0f6dd7f7e57586]. Read together, this means the scrutineers report is not only a mandatory component of each confirmation application, but it may also be expanded to include diagnostic commentary and root-cause analysis to assist the PRA’s assessment, particularly in cases where invalid voting could be material to the integrity of the member decision-making process.
source_text: The parties in an amalgamation should make a joint application for confirmation to the PRA, while the parties to a transfer of engagements should make separate applications for confirmation of the transfer. These applications should specify the date on which the merger is intended to take effect and should be accompanied by two authenticated copies of the Instrument of Transfer, or the amalgamation agreement, and of the Merger Document or separate Schedule 16 Statement. In addition, in the case of an amalgamation, three signed copies of the Memorandum and Rules of the successor 34 to the amalgamating societies should be sent to the PRA and the FCA. The scrutineers report described in paragraphs 3.146 to 3.148 , and a certified copy of the minutes of the general meeting at which the Merger Resolutions were moved, must be enclosed with each application.
target_text: The PRA would find it helpful if the scrutineers report would also comment upon any procedural difficulties encountered and give an analysis of the reasons why votes were found to be invalid, if the numbers of invalid votes appear to be significant (see also paragraph 3.171 ).
